LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Islamic Republic of Pakistan 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sectors: Multisector 
Subsector:  Water supply and sanitation, waste management, 
integrated, multimodal transport 
Theme: Sustainable economic growth, governance, and capacity 
development 
Subtheme: Developing urban areas, public governance, 
institutional development 
   
Environment  Category C 
Assessment   
The technical assistance (TA) loan does not by itself have any 
environmental impact, but an environmental assessment will be an 
integral component of the subproject preparatory process that is 
financed  under  the  TA  loan.  The  Government  of  Pakistan  will 
provide  an  assurance  that  any  subproject  will  be  prepared  in 
accordance with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Environment 
Policy.  
   
Project Description  The  TA  loan  provides  a  key  intervention  of  the  long-term 
partnership between ADB and Pakistan for the development of 
Karachi.  It  responds  to  the  need  for  a  long-term  and  holistic 
approach to the development of Karachi whose large-scale needs 
for infrastructure and reforms cannot be met by the traditional 
approach of a one-off project. The TA loan supports a series of 
complementary interventions whose cumulative effect will produce 
the synergy to speed up the development process of the mega 
city  on  a  sustainable  basis.  These  interventions  involve 
comprehensive capacity building of city district government, town 
municipal administrations (TMAs), and other city agencies in city 
planning,  management,  and  adoption  and  implementation  of 
commercial principles in providing infrastructure and services. The 
TA loan interventions also include support for preparing bankable 
projects for the mega city infrastructure and services development 
in  an  efficient  and  integrated  manner.  Moreover,  the  TA  loan 
involves interventions for sustainable financing of the mega city 
infrastructure through introducing an innovative financing vehicle.  
   
Rationale  The  economy  and  population  of  Karachi  have  expanded 
significantly, but few investments have been made in the city’s 
urban  infrastructure  for  over  two  decades.  Infrastructure  and 
services  that  are  inadequate  and  unreliable  are  adding  to 
business  and  household  costs,  harming  Karachi’s  urban  and 
natural  environments,  and  decreasing  the  city’s  global 
competitiveness  compared  with  alternative  Asian  mega  cities. 
The  Government’s  recent  devolution  policy  provides  major 
benefits  to  be  realized,  but  it  has  left  many  issues  to  be 
addressed in such areas as (i) fiscal imbalance and unclear and 
incomplete  allocation  of  responsibilities  between  levels  of

ii   
government, and (ii) inadequacy of the city’s and towns’ financial 
and technical capacities to fully meet their new responsibilities 
within the devolved framework. There is a need for substantial 
and long-term capacity building at the city and town levels if 
devolution  is  to  yield  the  intended  benefits  for  more  effective 
urban service delivery. There is also increasing recognition that 
the  growing  gap  between  urban  infrastructure  demand  and 
current  supply  cannot  be  met  through  traditional  government 
sources,  including  local  government  revenues,  subsidies,  and 
transfers  from  the  higher  levels  of  government.  Alternative 
sources of financing and new ways of providing infrastructure and 
services are required.  
   
Impact and Outcome  The expected impact of the TA loan is an enhanced and sustained 
contribution of Karachi to national development and a sustainable 
improvement in the quality of life for the city residents, including 
the poor. The expected outcomes are (i) improved city planning, 
management, and financing; (ii) improved and expanded urban 
infrastructure  and  services;  and  (iii)  sustainable  and  efficient 
financing of urban infrastructure. To these ends, the TA loan will 
provide resources for (i) building the capacities of the City District 
Government  of  Karachi  (CDGK),  TMAs,  and  utilities  in  city 
planning,  management,  and  financing,  as  well  as  in  applying 
commercial  principles  in  the  provision  of  infrastructure  and 
services;  (ii)  assisting  to  prepare  bankable  projects  that  may 
subsequently  be  funded  by  ADB  in  its  lending  assistance  to 
Karachi  over  the  next  4  years;  and  (iii)  establishing  and 
operationalizing  an  innovative  financing  vehicle  for  mega  city 
infrastructure investments which will act as (a) an efficient conduit 
for channeling ADB and other funds to the city, (b) a catalyst for 
reforming the city agencies, and (c) an agent to mobilize funds 
from nongovernment sources for large-scale capital investment 
needs.  It  is  expected  that  the  TA  loan  will  also  enhance  the 
Government’s  ownership  of  the  investment  projects,  capacity 
building, and institutional reforms.  
   
Cost Estimates  The  total  cost  of  the  Project  is  estimated  at  $13.330  million 
equivalent, comprising a foreign exchange component of $6.460 
million (48% of the total cost) and a local currency component of 
$6.870 million equivalent (52% of the total cost).  
   
Financing Plan  ($ million) 
Source  Foreign  Local  Total  % 
Exchange  Currency  Cost

Government   0.0  3.33   3.33   25 
  Total  6.46  6.87  13.33   100 
 
  Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
Loan Amount and Terms  A loan of $10.0 million equivalent in special drawing rights (SDR) 
and various currencies from ADB's Special Funds resources will 
be provided. The loan will have a 32-year term including a grace 
period of 8 years, and with an interest rate of 1.0% per annum

iii
during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter. 
   
Period of Utilization  Until 31 July 2010 
   
Estimated Project  31 January  2010 
Completion Date 
   
Executing Agency  The Finance Department of the Government of Sindh (GOS) will 
be the Executing Agency. 
   
Implementation  A project support unit (PSU) will be established in the Finance 
Arrangements  Department  of  Sindh.  It  will  be  headed  by  a  full-time  Project 
Director and staffed with suitably qualified personnel. The PSU 
will  oversee  the  overall  project  and  be  responsible  for 
implementing part C (specialized financing vehicle). 
 
A project steering committee (PSC), chaired by the Government 
of Sindh’s Minister, Finance, will be formed. It will include the 
Minister  of  Planning  and  Development,  the  Minister  of  Local 
Government,  Nazim  (city  mayor),  CDGK,  Additional  Chief 
Secretary  (Development),  Planning  and  Development,  Sindh, 
Secretary Finance, Secretary Local Government, Sindh, District 
Coordination Officer of CDGK, and the Project Director, PSU and 
two representatives from NGOs/academia. Project Director PSU 
will act also as the secretary of the PSC. The PSC will provide 
policy  support,  oversee  project  progress,  facilitate  cooperation 
among agencies concerned, and ensure the timely undertaking of 
reform  actions  to  establish  and  operationalize  the  specialized 
financing vehicle and to implement organizational development, 
revenue  mobilization  and  financial  management,  and  other 
reforms  at  CDGK  and  the  TMAs.  The  committee  will  meet 
quarterly or upon request by any of its members.  
 
CDGK  will  be  the  Implementing  Agency  for  part  A  (Capacity 
Building  Facility)  and  part  B  (Project  Preparation  Facility).  A 
project working group (PWG), chaired by the district coordination 
officer,  will  be  formed  to  provide  oversight  for  all  operational 
matters and coordinate with part C. The PWG will meet bimonthly 
and have specific responsibility for approving the prioritization of 
subprojects,  final  terms  of  reference  (TORs),  and  consultant 
selection  for  subprojects  under  parts  A  and  B  prior  to  their 
submission to the PSU for onward transmittal to ADB. 
  
A  local  support  unit  (LSU)  will  be  established  in  CDGK  (the 
Department  of  Finance  and  Planning)  to  plan,  implement 
organizational development, and coordinate those activities and 
individual  programs  of  parts  A  and  B  which  will  mainly  be 
implemented by the individual subproject units in respective sector 
departments of CDGK.  
   
Procurement  All  goods  and  services  under  the  Project  will  be  procured  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement.

iv   
Consulting Services  International  and/or  domestic  consulting  firms  will  be  recruited 
using ADB’s quality and cost-based selection and quality-based 
selection procedures as appropriate for each subproject. Certain 
subprojects  will  utilize  quality-based  selection,  as  these  require 
expertise  of  limited  availability.  Consulting  firms  and  individual 
consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to 
ADB for engaging domestic consultants. 
 
Specialists in urban planning, water supply, sewerage, solid waste 
management, urban transport and roads, low income community 
upgrading,  private  sector  participation  in  urban  infrastructure 
provision, economics,  finance, social development,  resettlement, 
and  the  environment  will  help  CDGK  carry  out  comprehensive 
feasibility  analyses  and,  where  necessary,  engineering  designs, 
preparation  of  bid  documents,  and  procurement  of  goods  and 
services  in  a  manner  satisfactory  to  ADB.  Specialists  in  urban 
governance,  urban/municipal  finance,  institutional  development, 
and corporate governance will also be recruited to help design and 
implement programs under the capacity building facility. 
 
Tentative estimates of the consulting services requirements for the 
whole  TA  loan  are  about  145  and  430  person-months  of 
international and domestic consultants, respectively. 
   
Project Benefits and  The mega city’s population will realize sustainable benefits from 
Beneficiaries  improved  governance  and  CDGK’s  enhanced  capacities  for 
effective  city  planning,  management,  and  provision  of 
infrastructure  and  services.  This  will  be  achieved  through  (i) 
organizational  development  of  CDGK  within  the  devolved 
structure; (ii) managerial and technical capacity improvements; (iii) 
improved financial planning, budgeting, and reporting, as well as 
enhanced  local  revenues;  (iv)  customer  orientation  and 
commercialization reforms within CDGK, utilities, and TMAs; and 
(v) enhanced public, private, and community partnership in urban 
service provision.  
 
The TA loan through the project preparation facility will support 
Karachi’s economic development and poverty reduction by means 
of  efficient  and  timely  provision  of  funds  and  assistance  for 
preparing  bankable  subprojects.  The  subprojects  will  address 
high-priority  infrastructure  needs  and  the  needs  of  poor 
settlements that make up a substantial portion of the city. The 
immediate beneficiary will be the CDGK, whose gains will include 
improved  governance  and  transparency  in  consultant  selection 
and procurement and enhanced project preparation capacities.  
 
The TA loan will ensure sustainable development of the mega city 
by helping to establish and operationalize a viable, specialized 
mega city financing vehicle which will (i) act as an efficient conduit 
to channel funds to mega city infrastructure development, (ii) be 
an  important  catalyst  and  promoter  in  accelerating 
commercialization of urban infrastructure and services, and (iii) in

v
the  medium-to-long  term,  mobilize  funds  from  alternative 
nongovernment  sources.  The  ultimate  beneficiaries  will  be  the 
residents  and  businesses  of  not  only  the  Karachi  city  but  the 
country as a whole, since Karachi’s contribution to the economy 
goes beyond the city and province. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  Major potential risks include those related to (i) possible delays in 
project implementation due to inadequate capacities of CDGK, 
(ii) possible delays in government reform actions to implement the 
proposed improvements under the capacity building component,  
and  (iii)  a  possible  lack  of  cooperation  from  civil  society  and 
nongovernment organizations.  
 
To  mitigate  the  possible  delays  in  project  implementation,  the 
Project provides support for TA loan management whereby a core 
team of experts/advisors is to be engaged at the Project’s outset 
to assist the PSU, PWG, and LSU in reviewing and revising the 
scope of components, prioritizing subprojects, finalizing the TORs, 
recruiting consultants and evaluating the consultant outputs.   
 
The  risk  of  delay  in  government  actions  to  implement  the 
proposed  reforms  for  organizational  development,  tariffs,  local 
revenues, financial management, corporatization, and customer 
orientation  will  be  mitigated  by  close  ADB  supervision  of 
implementation.  ADB  will  be  actively  engaged  throughout  the 
progress of the capacity building subprograms, and especially in 
those  having  policy  and  sector  reform  implications.  Each 
subprogram will identify the time-bound actions to be taken by the 
Government at the early stages of its implementation and which 
will form the content of the policy dialogue with CDGK, GOS and 
ADB. In addition, the PSC will use its considerable political and 
administrative clout to facilitate timely implementation of reform 
actions.  
 
Finally, the additional risk that may emerge due to possible lack of 
cooperation from civil society will be addressed through involving 
the  representatives  of  the  nongovernment  organizations  in  the 
PSC, and ensuring the participation of the civil society, business 
community, and the urban poor in developing and implementing 
the subprojects.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
technical assistance (TA) loan to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the Mega City Development 
Project. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES   
 
A.  Introduction  
 
2.  In its midterm development framework, the Government of Pakistan (Government) made 
a commitment to enhance the competitiveness of and quality of life in its large cities. The 
Government constituted a high-level committee led by the Planning Commission for coordinated 
development of its mega cities, starting with Karachi as a central plank in its long-term economic 
development strategy. In this context, the Government requested Asian Development Bank's 
(ADB) assistance to address the mega city challenges facing Pakistan. Given the immense size 
of Karachi, the magnitude of its investment requirements, and the scale of interventions for urban 
policy reforms, both ADB and the Government recognized that the needs of Karachi cannot be 
addressed  by  a  one-off  approach,  but,  rather  require  a  series  of  appropriately  sequenced 
interventions. Accordingly, ADB’s country strategy and program update (CSPU) for 2005–2006 
included a TA loan1 in 2005, as the first intervention of the long-term mega city assistance 
program to enable the Government to undertake preparation of priority projects, critically needed 
urban institutional and financial reforms, and comprehensive capacity building.  
 
B.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
3.  Economy. Karachi, the capital of Sindh province, is the commercial hub and gateway of 
Pakistan. It accounts for 95% of Pakistan’s foreign trade and contributes 30% of Pakistan’s 
industrial production. Nearly 90% of the country’s head offices of banks, financial institutions and 
multinational companies are located in Karachi. The country’s largest stock exchange is Karachi-
based. The city contributes 20% of the national gross domestic product, accounts for 40% of 
national employment in large-scale manufacturing, and contributes 25% of national and 40% of 
provincial revenues.  
 
4.  Demography. According to the 1998 census, Karachi had a population of 9.2 million in 
1998, which compares with 5.2 million in 1981. Based upon the intercensal (1981–1998) annual 
growth rate of 4.5%, the current population of Karachi is estimated at 12.5 million and the 
population is projected to reach 20.7 million in 2015. The city is made up of 18 contiguous towns.  
 
5.  Mega City Development Trends. The geographical location and economic potential of 
Karachi have drawn both labor and capital for many decades, but the city has never been in a 
position to maximize this potential to benefit the city. Little investment into the city’s infrastructure 
has been made over the past two decades. Neither new investments nor new additions to the 
labor force have been optimally located in the city, resulting in haphazard development, a polluted 
urban environment, and, for many households, a poor quality of life.  
 
6.  Poverty. Based on the 2001 poverty line2 and the fiscal year 2001–2002 income levels3 
for Karachi, 50% of the city’s total population is poor. The pattern of household income shows

3

2   
that around 9.5% of the households are living in extreme and chronic poverty while another 14% 
are transitory poor. The incidence of poverty varies in the 18 towns and the cantonment areas in 
the city. The highest incidence is in katchi abadis, which are informally developed and poor 
settlements. It is estimated that 89% of the population of katchi abadis lives below the poverty 
line.  
 
7.  Urban Environment. Karachi both faces and causes significant environmental issues and 
pressures. Outside the mega city, the major environmental resources adversely affected by 
activities in the city are the coastline and the near-shore marine habitat. More than 900,000 cubic 
meters (some 200 million gallons) per day of untreated domestic and industrial wastewater and 
over 1,000 tons per day of uncollected solid waste finds its way directly or indirectly to the sea, 
providing  a  constant  source  of  marine  pollution.  Karachi’s  industries  generate  a  cocktail  of 
chemicals and toxic substances, and a significant amount of industrial effluent is discharged into 
creeks, rivers, or the sea. New development takes place within environmentally sensitive areas 
and reserves for critical infrastructure, causing major environmental problems. Vehicle-generated 
air pollution is severe, with high concentrations of suspended particulate matter in the air causing 
respiratory problems among a large number of mega city residents.  
 
C.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
1.  Inadequate Mega City Management: Need for Capacity Building  
 
8.  Mega City Governance in Transition. The weak city governance and management 
systems lead to poor performance in planning and provision of infrastructure and services in the 
mega city. The devolution reforms of 2001 have ushered in a need for major restructuring of the 
local  government  through  transfer  of  political  and  administrative  power  to  the  elected  local 
authorities.  The  City  District  Government  of  Karachi  (CDGK)  became  the  central  player  in 
managing the city’s affairs while the town municipal administrations (TMAs) of 18 towns were 
tasked with core municipal functions, including town planning and provision of infrastructure and 
services for water, sanitation, roads, streetlights, etc. Although the devolution has provided a 
good  opportunity  for  effective  service  provision,  it  has  led  to  continuing  overlaps  and 
fragmentation. Various agencies at provincial level remain responsible for service provision that is 
now the responsibility of CDGK and TMAs. The post-devolution institutional structure of CDGK is 
primarily an outcome of joining past provincial offices and their employees into CDGK, rather than 
any major reorganization needed to undertake the management of a mega city along modern 
lines (see the organization of CDGK in Appendix 2).  
 
9.  In the devolution process, the capacity of some technically well-endowed agencies, such 
as  the  Karachi  Development  Authority,  was  lost  without  providing  an  alternative  devolved 
structure for them. The restructuring of such major service providers as Karachi Water and 
Sewerage Board (KWSB) and coordination with the TMAs remain to be addressed. Personnel 
administration within the devolved setup continues to be an issue. While the provincial staff were 
physically transferred to CDGK, they remain administratively under the Government of Sindh 
(GOS),  limiting  the  power  of  CDGK  on  personnel  matters  and  undermining  employee  and 
management accountability. The organization is overstaffed, with a concentration of low-grade 
employees. A large majority of the staff does not have the qualifications and skills required to 
discharge the new responsibilities and facilitate evolution of an accountable work ethic in CDGK.  
 
10.  There is a need to introduce appropriate institutional structures, business practices, and 
improved capacities if the devolution is to yield the intended benefits with regard to improved 
governance and effective service delivery. This would require (i) evolution of new regulatory 
relationships between GOS, CDGK, and the TMAs, with GOS and CDGK assuming greater roles 
for regulation and oversight; (ii) clarity of functional responsibilities between GOS and CDGK, as 
well as within CDGK; (iii) organizational development of CDGK and the TMAs; (iv) introducing 
customer  orientation  and  commercialization  in  CDGK  and  utilites;  and  (v)  human  resource

3
management that combines rationalization strategies, training, and personnel management for a 
productive workforce in CDGK and TMAs. These improvements form the priority subprograms of 
capacity building assistance in the Project.  
  
11.  Lack of Planned Approach to Development. Inadequate planning systems resulted in 
haphazard growth of the mega city. The current planning system has not articulated into plans the 
strategic directions and visions for the city’s economic development. The planning system is 
neither linked to prioritized action plans nor to financial strategies needed to realize them. The 
recent  master  plan,  prepared  for  the  period  up  to  2000,  was  not  adopted  due  to  lack  of 
institutional clarity for approving and implementing plans. Master planning has been constrained 
by (i) a lack of strategic guidance, (ii) institutional uncertainty, (iii) land management issues of the 
mega  city,  and  (iv)  ineffective  building  control  and  enforcement.  The  situation  has  been 
aggravated by the fact that nearly 90% of city land is under the ownership of various public 
institutions, each of which has authority over land use and planning with regard to its own land.  
 
12.  Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) has recently supported a study4 for the 
“revitalization of Karachi.” A vision for Karachi was established as a “cosmopolitan gateway city” 
of international business and tourism. This vision would be achieved through (i) social upgrading, 
involving tourism and business infrastructure and amenities, welfare services, skills upgrading, 
and  citizen  mobilization;  and  (ii)  urban  and  industrial  development  through  infrastructure 
development,  possible  renovation  of  Karachi’s  circular  railway,  and  improving  the  urban 
environment. There remains a need, however, to translate this vision into concrete plans and 
programs. CDGK recently embarked on preparing an updated mega city master plan. Building on 
the work done by JBIC, the proposed TA loan will support CDGK in its endeavor for mega city 
planning.  The  planning  assistance  is  also  aimed  to  be  instrumental  in  developing  and 
institutionalizing a planning system that (i) integrates economic, social, environmental and spatial 
planning; (ii) is linked to financing strategies for implementing the plans; (iii) is based on clear 
institutional roles to approve and implement the plans; and (iv) is supplemented by effective 
development and building control systems.  
 
13.  Limited Revenue Base. The available funds of CDGK and the TMAs are not sufficient to 
offer the level of infrastructure services needed to support a reasonable quality of life in Karachi. 
Under the devolution, expenditure obligations of CDGK and the TMAs have been substantially 
extended. It is commonly perceived, however, that devolution assigned weak fiscal revenue 
bases. There remain deficiencies in the transfer system among levels of government, such as a 
lack of incentives for increasing local revenue performance at the city level. The existing local 
revenue base—which primarily consists of local taxation in the forms of property taxes, land 
revenue, and entertainment tax, as well as service charges especially for water, sewerage, and 
solid waste collection—is further reduced by  weak capacities to levy and collect taxes and 
charges and inadequate tariff structures and rates. It is estimated that CDGK’s own-source 
revenues constitute only 49% of total revenues while those of the TMAs range from 36% to 56%.  
   
14.  There is a need to expand the resources available to CDGK and the TMAs by improving 
the fiscal transfer system and local own-source revenues. The current efforts of GOS to develop 
a sound fiscal transfer system need to be supported in coordination with other relevant initiatives 
(e.g., ADB’s decentralization support program). With regard to own-source revenues, there is 
considerable scope to improve the yield of property tax by (i) computerization of records; (ii) 
shifting the base from annual rental value to transaction value; and (iii) removing tax exemptions 
by inclusion of military, federal and provincial properties, as well as household and commercial 
properties that are currently excluded from the tax net. It is estimated that by including exempted 
and  unrecorded  properties,  revenues  could  be  expanded  by  at  least  50%.  User  charges—
especially for water, sewerage, and solid waste—present another area for greater scope in 
increasing local revenues. Current tariffs are low and remain unchanged since 1998, even as 
                                                 
4 JBIC. 2004. Karachi Vitalization Scenario.  Pakistan.

4   
utility expenses have increased by 40% over the same period. The majority of users are not 
metered.  User  fees  are  charged  on  the  basis  of  plot  or  flat  sizes  and  are  not  based  on 
consumption. Currently, KWSB cannot meet its operating costs without subsidy. There is an 
urgent need to devise and implement tariff structures and rates that provide adequate revenues 
to cover cash operating costs, proper operations and maintenance, debt service, depreciation 
and a share of future capital expenditure.      
 
15.  CDGK’s  current  financial  management  systems  are  complex  and  fragmented.  An 
integrated  accounting  and  reporting  system  is  needed.  The  two  fund  streams  (local  and 
provincial) that continue, despite the legal amendments, need to be merged. A strong system of 
financial accounting and reporting should be evolved by strengthening CDGK’s Department of 
Finance  and  Planning  and  making  it  mandatory  to  furnish  regular  accounting  and  financial 
information. Accounts offices need also to be set up in towns to integrate TMA accounting within 
the entire system. All these efforts need to be supported by management information systems. 
Developing  and  implementing  a  revenue  enhancement  plan  (including  tariff  studies)  and 
improved financial management forms a major component of the capacity building assistance 
under the TA loan.  
 
16.  Inadequate financial management and revenues also limit the Karachi city government in 
effectively utilizing options for such financing alternatives as to outsource urban infrastructure 
development  and  management  to  the  private  sector.  Private  sector  participation  is  further 
hindered by (i) lack of clear policies and laws at the national, provincial, and local government 
levels to promote public-private partnerships (PPPs); and (ii) lack of institutional capacity in 
CDGK  to  develop,  analyze,  and  prepare  bankable  projects  as  well  as  to  structure,  tender, 
evaluate, contract out, negotiate, and regulate PPP transactions. The Private Participation in 
Infrastructure Development Project (PPID) currently being processed by ADB intends to address 
the above issues by creating an enabling policy and regulatory framework at the national level 
that will facilitate and complement the local reforms under the Project. 
 
17.  Untapped Sources of the Citizen Community Boards. Under the devolution, citizen 
community boards (CCBs) were organized to enhance community participation, cost sharing, 
operation and maintenance of development projects, and accountability. Devolution stipulated 
that 25% of the annual development funds of every town are to be spent through CCBs. While 
CCBs have been active elsewhere in the country, they have remained inactive in Karachi. As a 
result, millions of rupees earmarked for CCBs have accumulated and provide readily available 
funds for development. Mobilizing CCBs in Karachi would achieve public-community partnership 
for  development  projects  and  a  greater  accountability  over  the  use  of  development  funds. 
Activation of CCBs will therefore be an important element of capacity building activities.  
 
2.  Inadequate Infrastructure and Services and Need for Upgrading/Expansion  
 
18.  A major outcome of the weak governance and management of the mega city has been the 
inadequate urban infrastructure and services, including water supply, sewerage, drainage, solid 
waste management, urban transport and roads, and basic services for the city’s poor.  
 
19.  Water. While an estimated 82% of households have a water supply connection, water is 
available in the network only for a few hours every second day. With the exception of one or two 
towns, many households rely on tankers to supply potable water. System losses (technical and 
administrative)  are  high  and  occur  through  leakages,  illegal  connections,  and  the  lack  of 
metering. Water quality is poor, and over 75% of water samples taken from the system are below 
World Health Organization standards. This is due to (i) the lack of adequate treatment and poor 
functioning of treatment plants, and (ii) intermittent flow and variable pressures in the system. 
Problems are aggravated by a lack of long-term system planning for water supply and sewerage 
and insufficient cost-recovery measures that result in poor operation and maintenance.

5
20.  Sewerage and Drainage. Although an estimated 89% of households have a flush toilet, 
connected to either a sewer or septic tank, the sewerage network suffers from poor connectivity 
and a large number of undersized and broken sections. The sewerage treatment plants function 
at below their capacity due to inadequate maintenance and frequent blockages caused by solid 
waste  entering  the  plants.  Much  of  the  untreated  industrial  and  domestic  wastewater  is 
discharged into the stormwater drainage system and rivers and thence to Karachi Harbor and the 
Arabian Sea. A large part of the stormwater drainage functions as part of the wastewater disposal 
system. Most of the drainage lines are heavily encroached and used for disposing of solid waste. 
There is need (i) in the short term for programs to establish drainage rights of way and systems of 
routine maintenance, (ii) in the medium term for a drainage master plan, and (iii) for progressively 
achieving separation between wastewater and stormwater systems.      
 
21.  Solid Waste Management. An estimated 7,250 tons of solid waste is generated daily in 
the city. Only about 60% of this is collected, and no more than 25% of that amount makes it to 
one of the two designated city “landfill” sites—actually open dumping sites. The remainder is 
either recovered for recycling or is disposed of by burning or by illegal dumping into open spaces. 
The piles of uncollected waste are a nuisance and attract vermin that can carry disease. Informal 
solid  waste  recycling  is  significant.  The  poor  performance  in  solid  waste  management  is 
exacerbated by (i) lack of a practical waste management plan involving all stakeholders (e.g., the 
formal and informal private sectors), (ii) lack of mechanisms and sound feasibility studies required 
for outsourcing to the private sector, and (iii) inadequate capacities for tracking and monitoring of 
the solid waste systems. 
 
22.  Urban Transport. The city population relies almost entirely on the road network for urban 
transportation. There is currently no mass transit system per se, although many commute using 
the network of bus routes. Rapid growth rate of private vehicles (9% per annum) leads to 
overcrowding, air pollution, and accidents. While there has been a significant program of road 
building, no major investment in public transport systems has taken place. Attempts to revive the 
Karachi circular railway and a light rail mass transit system have failed to attract public or private 
investment. The quality of major thoroughfares is generally good, but the distributor network 
varies dramatically. The current focus on primary networks in the absence of a distributor network 
is resulting in reduced benefits from investments in primary networks. The sector operations have 
been adversely affected by (i) lack of clarity on institutional roles and overlapping responsibilities 
between several departments of CDGK5 and (ii) lack of a transport master plan to guide future 
development of roads and public transport and a strategy for financing the city’s transport system. 
A detailed infrastructure assessment is in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
23.  One common issue across all infrastructure subsectors is the poor standard of project 
identification and preparation, which subsequently leads to poor performance in infrastructure and 
services.  This  issue  further  reinforces  (i)  disjointed  and  inefficient  infrastructure  and  service 
provision,  (ii)  failure  of  projects  to  achieve  their  anticipated  benefits,  (iii)  poor  project 
sustainability, and (iv) inability to access commercial financing for public infrastructure provision. 
The proposed TA loan will assist CDGK in selecting and developing bankable projects to address 
the mega city’s high-priority infrastructure and service needs. 
 
24.  Katchi Abadis. Katchi abadis, in which 40% of the city population lives, are created by 
informal settlers. They are located on public or privately-owned land without legal property rights. 
These  settlements  have  grossly  limited  access  to  public  water  supply,  sewage,  and  other 
services. They invest a significant part of their incomes to purchase potable water and construct 
in-house septic tanks to dispose of wastewater. About 70% of households are connected to the 
public sector’s piped water supply system. The remaining population depends on unprotected 
                                                 
5 Recently the two units were consolidated under the same director general, but the full integration will likely take time.

6   
sources and, on average, spends 5–8% of its monthly income to purchase water, which is an 
additional factor contributing to poverty.  
 
25.  The estimated number of these settlements is over 1,000, of which 539 have already been 
listed for regularization and upgrading in line with the Government’s policy. Expansion of these 
settlements continues at a rate of some 10% per year, and this requires urgent attention. A two-
pronged approach is required that involves (i) upgrading, where possible, of existing squatter 
settlements with minimum displacement and (ii) developing a shared strategy for those katchi 
abadis that cannot benefit from on-site upgrading. Coalitions of nongovernment organizations 
(NGOs), community groups, and CCBs must be formed if this approach is to be successful.       
 
  3.  Need for an Innovative Financing Mechanism   
 
26.  The mega city infrastructure backlogs are too huge6 to be financed through the traditional 
public sector sources, even if their potential were fully exploited. The funding gap in meeting the 
city’s infrastructure requirements will need to be met through alternative financing in the form of 
long-tenor debt. However, currently neither CDGK nor the TMAs have the capacity to access 
commercial financing and to raise private finance through the capital markets for long-term funds 
even  if  they  were  empowered  to  do  so.  More  viable  institutions,  performing  financial 
intermediation functions that would specialize on Karachi’s urban infrastructure sector and that 
can pool risks and manage investor concerns, would be needed to enable CDGK and the TMAs 
to access nongovernment sources of financing.  
 
27.  Moreover, it is commonly perceived that the Government has not been efficient in the role 
of funds provider to the sector, as its allocation of funds has not been driven by commercial 
rationale. In this environment, the federal, provincial, and city governments all strongly support 
introducing a specialized financing vehicle (SFV) for the mega city that would (i) act in the short 
term as an efficient conduit to channel funds from ADB and other development partners to 
Karachi infrastructure projects; (ii) provide technical assistance in preparing infrastructure projects 
to bankable standards, and monitor funded projects to ensure loan repayment; and (iii) in the 
medium-to-long term catalyze funds from nongovernment sources for sustainable financing of city 
infrastructure and services. The SFV is envisaged to provide commercial and concessional funds 
(depending on the ultimate design and mandate of the vehicle) both directly to infrastructure 
projects and indirectly to other fund providers (such as in the form of guarantees to private sector 
players investing in infrastructure and services).  
 
28.  A comparison of two scenarios—with and without a financing vehicle—for the mega city 
shows that introducing a mega city financing vehicle will facilitate allocation of financial capital 
investments to worthy projects and borrowers. The vehicle will provide an incentive mechanism 
for enhancing the tariff structures, financial discipline, and creditworthiness by enforcing improved 
budgeting, auditing, and disclosure standards at CDGK, TMAs and the utilities. It will provide a 
mechanism through which CDGK, the TMAs and utilities can gain credit experience and history 
so that they can gradually gain access to commercially based credits. Through tying funds 
allocation to commercial principles, the SFV will act as an important catalyst and promoter of 
accelerated capacity building, sound project preparation, financial reforms, commercialization of 
infrastructure  providers,  and,  over  time,  private  financing  for  providing  and  managing 
infrastructure  and  services  in  Karachi  and  possibly  in  Sindh.  Introduction  of  a  specialized 
financing vehicle for the mega city will therefore constitute a major component of the TA loan.  
 
                                                 
6 The estimated overall cost of priority subprojects in Appendix 5 (excluding mass transit) is about $350 million. The 
overall cost of short-term projects in CDGK’s midterm development plan is estimated at above $1.165 billion. Based 
on a methodology that relates growth in per capita income to the need for expanded urban infrastructure, it is 
estimated that $0.5 billion to $1.0 billion per year is required to maintain an adequate stock of infrastructure in 
Karachi. The actual requirement may be higher due to the poor state of existing infrastructure stock.

7
29.  Due to strong demand from the three levels of government for an SFV for the mega city, 
the feasibility and design of the SFV will be undertaken by parallel TA7 to be provided by ADB 
ahead of commencing the TA loan implementation. Upon completion of the feasibility study and 
design of the SFV, the TA loan, then, will assist in establishing and operationalizing the vehicle.  
 
30.  Establishing a mega city financing vehicle, however, will not automatically and by itself 
result in making extensive sources of alternative funds available for Karachi’s infrastructure. It 
must be accompanied by other reforms, including (i) a supportive framework for appropriate tariff 
schedules;  (ii)  a  better  fiscal  balance  between  different  levels  of  government;  (iii)  resource 
mobilization  at  the  local  level;  (iv)  CDGK  operating  on  a  more  efficient  basis;  (v) 
commercialization of water, sanitation, and other service providers; (vi) management systems, 
including accounting practices, that allow disclosure of amounts due to and from others, (vii) 
changes in attitudes of residents about paying tariffs; and (viii) well designed, bankable projects 
with tariff structures to recover costs of capital, operation and maintenance, and with enhanced 
project management capacities to create assets quickly so that incomes from investments begin 
to accrue without delay. All these reforms are important elements of the comprehensive capacity 
building program under the TA loan. The reforms for establishing the SFV for the mega city and 
the reforms for capacity building at city level will be complementary to ADB’s ongoing PPID 
initiative at the national level.  
 
31.  While Pakistan’s financial sector has been significantly reformed over the past decade, 
with ADB and other external assistance, there has been virtually no commercial lending and 
private financing of urban infrastructure projects in Karachi and other cities. Thus, the SFV would 
not compete with existing financial institutions in the country. Rather, the SFV, working closely 
with ADB, governments, and existing financial intermediaries, would help to develop a market for 
commercial lending and private financing of urban infrastructure that could subsequently be 
accessed by the existing financial intermediaries.  
 
  4.  External Assistance and Lessons Learned from ADB assistance  
 
32.  Since 1976, ADB has provided eight loans to the urban sector, totaling about $450 million, 
and a further $6.75 million for TA in the water supply, sanitation, and urban development sectors. 
Two loans8 were provided to Karachi in the urban sector 20 and 15 years ago, respectively. The 
city has also been the beneficiary of two ADB programs: the Decentralization Support Program 
and the Sindh Devolved Social Services. Moreover, ADB is currently funding TA in Sindh on 
environmental management that should also benefit Karachi.  
 
33.  The World Bank provided assistance to Karachi in the past in the water supply and power 
sectors. Its current assistance is through GOS, with which it has a line of structural adjustment 
credit. Another initiative under the World Bank’s umbrella is support of the Water and Sanitation 
Program to KWSB on institutional strengthening. In recent years, the principal bilateral source of 
investment in the urban sector in Karachi has been the Government of Japan, particularly in the 
water supply, sewerage, and transport sectors. KWSB is completing a water treatment project 
supported by JBIC, which also assisted in preparing the “Revitalization Scenario” for Karachi. The 
Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) has begun preparing a master plan for Karachi’s 
water supply and sewerage, and it has plans to support preparation of a transport master plan for 
the city. The list of external assistance is attached as Appendix 3.

34.  Lessons learned from the two ADB loan projects to Karachi (footnote 8), which were 
evaluated as “unsuccessful” and “partially successful,” include the need for (i) greater attention to 
sustainability,  (ii)  enhanced  project  design  based  on  sound  assessments,  (iii)  careful 
consideration for institutional shortcomings of executing and implementing agencies, and (iv) 
greater efforts to address the financial insolvency problems of the Karachi local government 
bodies. A specific lesson derived from the previous Karachi Urban Development Project is that 
urban upgrading is complex and must be able to deal with the broad range of problems faced by 
katchi abadis dwellers, including that of regularization and security of tenure. All these lessons 
suggest that urban development assistance demands a holistic approach. To be of lasting value, 
major capital investments need to be supported by capacity building, policy, legal, regulatory, and 
institutional reforms, as well as new and innovative financing vehicles that facilitate provision of 
high-quality infrastructure services on a sustainable basis. The proposed project incorporates 
these lessons into its design.  
  5.  Summary of the Rationale 
 
35.  The economy and population of Karachi have expanded significantly, but provision of 
infrastructure and services has not kept pace with this rapid growth in the absence of funds and 
adequate mega city governance and management systems. Infrastructure and services that are 
insufficient and unreliable are adding to business and household costs, hurting Karachi’s urban 
and  natural  environments,  and  decreasing  the  city’s  global  competitiveness  compared  with 
alternative Asian mega cities.  
 
36.  Devolution has provided opportunities for effective service delivery but left many issues to 
be addressed in areas such as (i) fiscal imbalance, limited revenues, and unclear and incomplete 
allocation of responsibilities between levels of government; and (ii) the inadequacy of the city’s 
and towns’ financial and technical capacities to fully meet their new responsibilities within the 
devolved framework. There is need for substantial and long-term capacity building at the city level 
if the devolution is to yield the intended benefits for improved governance and more effective 
urban service delivery. There is also increasing recognition that the growing gap between urban 
infrastructure demand and current supply cannot be met through traditional government sources, 
including  local  government  revenues,  subsidies,  and  transfers  from  the  higher  levels  of 
government.  Alternative  sources  of  financing  and  new  ways  of  providing  infrastructure  and 
services are required. Provision of urban infrastructure services need to be placed on a fully 
commercial and self-sustaining basis. Meanwhile, necessary regulatory and institutional reforms 
should be effected.   
 
37.    Previous external assistance in Karachi has been piecemeal and has not been based 
upon an integrated approach to improve urban infrastructure and services on a sustainable basis. 
The proposed TA loan is intended to address the mega city development needs with a long-term 
and holistic approach through (i) building capacities at the local level for effective city planning 
and  management,  (ii)  adopting  and  implementing  commercial  principles  in  the  provision  of 
infrastructure and services, (iii) supporting the preparation of bankable projects for mega city 
development that may subsequently be funded by ADB in its loans to Karachi initially over the 
next 4 years, and (iv) promoting reforms for sustainable financing. The TA loan represents the 
first intervention of a long-term assistance from ADB, and it will establish the required foundation 
for effectively utilizing and sustaining future ADB investments in the mega city.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
38.  The immense size of Karachi, the magnitude of its investment requirements, and the scale 
of the needs for urban policy and institutional reforms suggest that a traditional approach of one-
off projects will not work. There is need for a series of appropriately sequenced and integrated

9
interventions whose cumulative effect will act as a catalyst to speed up the development process 
in Karachi.  
 
39.  The expected impact of the TA loan is an enhanced and sustained contribution of Karachi 
to national development and an improved quality of life for its residents, including the poor. The 
anticipated outcomes are (i) improved city planning, management, and financing; (ii) improved 
and expanded urban infrastructure and services; and (iii) sustainable and efficient financing of 
mega city urban infrastructure and services. To these ends, the TA loan will provide resources for 
(i) building the capacities of CDGK, the TMAs and utilities in city planning, management, and 
financing, as well as in adopting and implementing commercial principles in the provision of 
infrastructure and services; (ii) assistance in preparing bankable projects for expanding and 
improving mega city infrastructure and services that may subsequently be funded by ADB or 
other development partners in their lending assistance to Karachi; and (iii) establishment and 
operationalization of an SFV for the mega city infrastructure and services. It is expected that the 
TA loan will also enhance the governments’ sense of ownership of the investment projects, 
capacity building, and institutional reforms.  
 
B.  Outputs 
 
40.   The TA loan comprises four parts: part A: Capacity Building Facility for CDGK, TMAs and 
utilities in planning, managing, and financing urban infrastructure and services; part B: Project 
Preparation Facility; part C: Establishment and Development of SFV; and part D: Support for TA 
Loan Management.    
 
1.  Part A: Capacity Building Facility  
   
41.   The objective of part A is to make a pool of resources available to CDGK and other city 
agencies to undertake a comprehensive capacity building program. Areas for capacity building 
have already been identified and may be further reviewed and updated during the TA loan 
implementation. A priority activity under part A will be organizational development of CDGK and 
completion of its transition under the devolution. This will include (i) review and evolution of new 
regulatory relationships between GOS, CDGK and the TMAs; (ii) clarifying and developing the 
functional  responsibilities  within  CDGK  and  the  TMAs;  and  (iii)  reorganization  of  CDGK  to 
appropriately  reflect  the  new  mandates.  Other  major  components  of  the  capacity  building 
assistance are (i) financial management and revenue improvements, (ii) enhancing accounting 
and  establishing  management  information  systems  within  CDGK  and  TMAs,  (iii)  customer 
orientation  within  CDGK  and  TMAs,  (iv)  reforms  for  commercialization  of  KWSB,  and  (v) 
revitalization of CCBs to promote community and public partnership in the delivery of urban 
services. These activities will be supported by human resource management and rationalization 
strategies and training programs. Capacity building assistance will also include support for mega 
city planning through assistance in (i) building capacities for and institutionalization of strategic 
planning; (ii) master planning and preparation of a sector investment program; and (iii) developing 
and implementing reforms to address the weaknesses of current planning practices in terms of 
institutional  roles  and  capacities,  land  management,  development  control  and  building 
regulations. The detailed scope of the subprograms under the capacity building facility is provided 
in Appendix 4. 
 
42.  To ensure institutional reform, time-bound reform action plans, to be agreed by GOS and 
CDGK, will be developed at the early stages of the capacity building subprograms. Adherence to 
these action plans will be sought to ensure that the capacity building assistance will bring a 
change in the mega city’s governance and management. Investment subprojects will also identify 
the required subsector reforms to provide the content of policy dialogue to be pursued during 
processing of the follow-on loans.

10   
2.  Part B: Project Preparation Facility 
    
43.  Part B will provide resources for preparing feasibility studies for bankable projects. It will 
address the poor standard of project planning, identification, and preparation, as well as the need 
for integrated development of investments. The resources for selecting and developing bankable 
projects will be used flexibly in response to evolving priorities. The feasibility studies will establish 
the technical, financial, institutional, economic, social and environmental feasibility of projects 
proposed for funding. The facility will also provide advisory services in developing public-private 
modalities for financing, constructing, operating and maintaining infrastructure facilities, as well as 
for preparing and vetting documents related to projects with private-public participation. Particular 
attention will be given to transferring knowledge and skills in project preparation to CDGK and the 
utilities. The studies will be carried out in accordance with ADB guidelines and methodologies to 
assess the financial feasibility, economic benefits, costs, distributional effects, social and poverty-
reduction impacts and benefits. They will examine resettlement costs, environmental impacts, 
and effects on gender equity and indigenous peoples. Based on the mega city infrastructure 
assessments, a number of projects that were identified as high priority are proposed for feasibility 
assessments under the TA loan. During the TA loan implementation, these may be further 
reviewed and replaced with new projects identified on the basis of agreed criteria, which, in turn, 
will become the project prescreening tool to be employed by the specialized financing vehicle. 
Where needed, resources under the project preparation facility may also be used to prepare 
detailed design work to accelerate project implementation. Profiles of the priority subprojects are 
provided in Appendix 5.  
 
44.  Water, Sewerage, and Drainage. The subprojects proposed for feasibility study in these 
subsectors aim to address the key issues responsible for the poor quality of infrastructure and 
services. Although a master plan for water and sewerage is currently being prepared by JICA, 
there is no drainage master plan. The subprojects are directed to enhancing the utility of existing 
systems and networks through (i) water loss reduction, (ii) sewerage and drainage rationalization 
and system strengthening, (iii) increasing sewage treatment capacities to address the major 
environmental and health issues caused by water pollution, (iv) preparation of a drainage master 
plan, and (v) developing effective operation and maintenance strategies. These subprojects are 
supported by advisory studies on tariff reforms and organizational development and by capacity 
building assistance to reinforce the sustainability of rehabilitated infrastructure and services.  
 
45.  Solid Waste Management. In this subsector, the proposed priority assistance aims to 
support Government initiatives in privatizing primary waste collection and disposal, along with 
rationalization  and  development  of  the  solid  waste  management  system.  This  involves 
(i) improved  systems  for  contracting  out  management  and  monitoring  of  the  private  sector 
collection system; (ii) design of optimal arrangements for continued involvement of the informal 
sector in recycling, reuse and recovery of waste; (iii) identification of garbage transfer sites, and 
arrangements  for  contracting  out  management  and  monitoring  of  the  bulk  system,  where 
possible, through public-private partnerships; and (iv) determination of optimal landfill sites and 
proposals  for  design,  construction,  and  operation  of  the  sites,  where  feasible,  through 
public-private partnership. 
 
46.  Roads and Transport. In this subsector, strategic emphasis is placed on mass transit 
systems. Proposed assistance includes advisory services to the Mass Transit Cell for (i) a critical 
review of the 1991 mass transit network proposal and development of a strategy and action plan 
to fund the priority elements of this network, (ii) dissemination of information on the plans and 
obtaining of government and public support for the proposals, (iii) completion of work to ensure 
that the plans meet government and ADB’s safeguards requirements, and (iv) development of a 
strategy for implementing the mass transit network under a private-public partnership modality. 
While the services do not include a transport master plan, close coordination will be maintained 
with JICA, which intends to prepare the transport master plan. Interventions in the urban transport 
sector will also incorporate components for air pollution control and air quality management,

11
considering that urban transport is the biggest source of air pollution in Karachi. While the 
strategic emphasize is on mass transit, it is recognized that this development will take time. 
Therefore, well justified investments for new roads may also be included among the selected 
priority subprojects.                    
 
47.  Katchi Abadis. To develop the metropolis as a city without squatters, the slow pace of 
upgrading katchi abadis needs to be accelerated while complementary long-term efforts are 
required to address the issue of their proliferation. The project interventions include a program 
combining (i) in situ upgrading of katchi abadis and (ii) a shared strategy for those katchi abadis 
whose in situ upgrading presents difficulties, through innovative and pro-poor redevelopment 
schemes and mechanisms to facilitate the access of the poor to land and services. It is also 
recognized  that  initiatives  for  katchi  abadis  improvements  must  be  placed  within  a  broader 
context of (i) national urbanization strategies to establish a balanced urban structure in the 
province  and  the  country,  (ii)  policies  related  to  migration,  and  (iii)  economic  strategies  to 
generate higher levels of production and income in other cities and regions outside Karachi. 
These are the mandates of the mega city coordination committee that is chaired by the Planning 
Commission  at  the  national  level. The  summary  poverty  reduction  and  social strategy  is  in 
Appendix 6.  
 
3.  Part C: Specialized Financing Vehicle  
 
48.  Part C will support the establishment and operationalization of an innovative financing 
vehicle to address the needs for long-term and sustainable financing of mega city infrastructure 
and services. The SFV will be a dedicated urban infrastructure financing entity that provides 
(depending on its design and development stage) concessional and commercial funds to CDGK, 
its utilities, TMAs, and possibly the private sector investing in urban infrastructure and services in 
Karachi (and perhaps in Sindh). It is envisaged that the role, products and services, operating 
principles, and financial strategy of the SFV will evolve. The specialized financing vehicle will act 
in the short term as an efficient conduit for channeling funds to mega city infrastructure and 
services.  It  will  have  transparent  criteria  applicable  to  loans  and  concessional  funds. 
Criteria-based allocation of funds that is coupled with advisory services for preparing bankable 
projects will encourage financial discipline and commercial principles in CDGK and its utilities. 
CDGK and the utilities that draw on the resources of the SFV will be expected to service their 
loans  out  of  the  financial  revenues/cash  flows  and  economic  benefits  generated  by  those 
investments funded by such loans. When designed and resourced in an appropriate manner, the 
SFV will be an important catalyst in gradually establishing a local debt culture and a reliable credit 
track for future borrowings. Consequently, it will help CDGK and its utilities in their transition 
toward commercial financing of infrastructure and services. In the long term, with enhanced local 
capacities and a maturing financial market, the SFV will act as an agent to mobilize funds for 
mega city infrastructure from nongovernment sources, including international financial institutions, 
domestic and international commercial lenders, and capital markets.  
 
49.  Given the Government’s strong commitment to accelerating the reforms for establishing 
the SFV, the feasibility and design of the SFV will be undertaken by a parallel TA (footnote 7) 
financed on a grant basis from ADB’s TA funding program. The TA, which will commence ahead 
of the TA loan implementation, will assess design features, legal structures, strategic road map, 
product types and terms for the SFV, and it will include due financial analysis to ensure the SFV’s 
viability and sustainability.  
 
50.  More specifically, the TA study will undertake (i) full analysis of economic and financial 
market conditions and trends, as well as coordination with PPID; (ii) analysis of the potential 
market for the SFV, quality of borrowers and projects; (iii) evaluation of design features and 
selection of an overall design that best meets Karachi’s needs; and (iv) selection of an existing 
financial intermediary, government and/or private sector partners to work with the TA in preparing 
the SFV’s detailed design. Further tasks will include completing the market demand analysis and

12   
marketing plan; estimating the financial resources required to make the SFV operational and 
viable; detailed financial analysis, including risks and uncertainties; preparation of the business 
case, business plan, and strategic road map for the SFV; and preparation of the operations 
manual to guide the SFV’s operations. Ownership and management structures of the SFV will be 
carefully  designed  to  ensure  a  professional  and  autonomous  management  and  a  powerful 
representation of stakeholders at board level. The intent is to maximize the SFV’s potential to 
serve as a force for reforms in Karachi. Due attention will be paid to analyzing the SFV’s role 
within the current governance framework to ensure that the SFV will enhance the devolved 
structure. Appendix 7 provides the detailed scope of the feasibility and design of the SFV to be 
prepared under the TA. Also provided is a summary of institutional roles with respect to the mega 
city urban infrastructure sector and the SFV’s potential role within that framework.  
 
51.   Upon completing the feasibility study and design, the TA loan under part C will assist in 
establishing and operationalizing the SFV (see the sequencing of SFV activities in Appendix 7). 
Early operation of the SFV would help in marketing its financial products and technical services, 
completing high-priority projects to bankable standards, and beginning staff recruitment, training 
and capacity building in order to expand skills, expertise, and domestic and international contacts 
in commercial infrastructure financing. Part C will provide start-up funding (seed money) for the 
SFV for the first 3 years until project flows and other financial products and services begin to 
generate significant revenues. Funding would decline through time as the SFV begins to generate 
revenues. Funding for year 1 would support a unit of 15 people, including salaries, benefits, and 
other administration costs as well as significant funding for capacity building and training. The 
subsidies in years 2 and 3 would cover the costs of about 10 and five staff, respectively, and the 
additional training in those years. The seed money could be repaid once the SFV becomes 
profitable.  
 
  4.  Part D: Support for TA Loan Management   
 
52.  Part D will include consultancy support to the project support unit (PSU) to be established 
in the Sindh Department of Finance (DOF) and the project working group (PWG) and local 
support unit (LSU) in CDGK. A core team of experts comprising three international advisors in (i) 
urban  governance  and  capacity  building,  (ii)  finance,  and  (iii)  infrastructure  planning  and 
engineering will be hired. These advisors will be supported by long-term local consultants. The 
core team will assist the PSU, PWG, and LSU in managing and implementing the overall project. 
The PSU in the DOF will be supported in overseeing the TA loan and implementing part C. The 
PWG and LSU in CDGK will be assisted in (i) ensuring coordination between various activities 
and studies of parts A and B; (ii) further refining the scope of the parts A and B and finalizing the 
scope of activities and terms of reference (TOR); (iii) determining the prioritization of project 
feasibility and other studies to be carried out; and (iv) finalizing detailed TORs for the subprojects 
and studies, preparing requests for proposals, and evaluating technical proposals for engaging 
consultants. At the outset, priority activities of the team will be to review the scope of the TA loan 
(especially parts A and B), review the scope of each study and subproject, and make justified and 
necessary adjustments and revisions in the overall scope of parts A and B and individual studies 
and subprojects. Facilitating, coordinating, and monitoring the development and implementation 
of reform action plans under the capacity building programs will form a critical task of the team. 
The team will also be responsible for assisting the PSU and LSU in evaluating the outputs of 
consultants for various subprojects. The detailed scope of part D is given in Appendix 8.

subproject. While not a concern under this project, future recurrent costs related to operations

and maintenance will be an issue for follow-on loans, and these will be incorporated into the 
TORs for each subproject. The detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 9.

D.  Financing Plan 
 
54.  The Government has requested ADB to provide a loan in the amount of $10.0 million 
equivalent from its Special Funds resources, representing 75% of the total project cost. The loan 
will have a term of 32 years including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per 
annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms and 
conditions as will be set forth in the draft loan agreement. The ADB loan will cover 100% of the 
foreign exchange cost and 51% of the local currency cost, excluding taxes. The financing plan is 
summarized in Table 2.  
 
55.  The borrower will be the Government of Pakistan, which will re-lend to the GOS on the 
same financial terms and conditions as those of the ADB loan. Counterpart funds of $3.33 million 
(25%) will be financed by the GOS and will cover local currency costs. Counterpart funds are 
expected  to  cover  items  such  as  (i)  remuneration  of  counterpart  staff,  (ii)  local  travel,  (iii) 
equipment and materials, (iv) surveys and data gathering, (v) taxes and duties, and (vi) other 
miscellaneous  costs.  As  most  of  these  funds  will  be  provided  in  kind,  the  availability  of 
counterpart financing should not be an issue. Availability of sufficient counterpart funds and 
resources to cover these costs was confirmed.
