E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
1.  TA Loan Management  
 
56.  The Executing Agency (EA) for the Project will be the DOF of the GOS. With the capacity, 
mandate, and a cadre of professional staff able to provide strategic and policy guidance, the DOF 
will be a powerful champion for the Project and especially able to guide development of the SFV.

14   
The EA will be responsible for overseeing the overall project as well as implementing part C. In 
addition, the EA will engage the consultants for part D in consultation with CDGK. A dedicated 
PSU will be established in the DOF and staffed with suitably qualified personnel. The Project 
Director  of  the  PSU  will  be    a  senior  ranking  officer  grade  BS.  19/20  from  DOF,  Sindh. 
Consultants who will assist in designing the SFV will be based in the DOF.  
 
57.  A project steering committee (PSC), chaired by the Government of Sindh’s Minister of 
Finance, will be formed. It will include the Minister, Planning and Development, Sindh; Minister, 
Local Government, Sindh; Nazim (Karachi city mayor), Additional Chief Secretary (Development); 
Planning  and  Development,  Sindh;  Secretary  Finance,  Sindh;  Secretary  Local  Government, 
Sindh; District Coordination Officer of CDGK, Project Director, PSU, and two representatives from 
NGO/academia. The project director, PSU will also act as the secretary of the PSC. The PSC will 
provide policy support, oversee project progress, facilitate coordination and cooperation among 
agencies concerned, and, more importantly, ensure the timely undertaking of reform actions to 
establish  and  operationalize  the  SFV  and  to  implement  revenue  mobilization  and  financial 
management reforms at the CDGK and TMA levels. The committee will meet quarterly, or upon 
request by any of its members. The Government may also form a committee to oversee the 
implementation of part C. The committee shall be chaired by Adviser to Prime Minister, on 
Finance/Minister of Finance. 
     
58.  CDGK will be the implementing agency for parts A and B (Capacity Building and Project 
Preparation facilities). A project working group (PWG), chaired by the district coordination officer 
and comprising executive district officers and managing directors of CDGK departments and 
utilities, will be formed to provide oversight for operational matters related to parts A and B and 
coordinating with part C. The PWG will meet bimonthly and be responsible for approving the 
prioritization of subprojects, final TORs, and consultant selection under parts A and B prior to 
their submission to the PSU for onward transmittal to ADB. The PWG will be responsible also for 
the  review,  approval,  and  timely  implementation  of  reform  action  plans  prepared  under  the 
subprograms of the capacity building facility. Coordination with the TMAs will be maintained 
through an ad hoc district-town coordination committee chaired by the district coordination officer 
and  consisting  of  chief  officers  of  TMAs.  The  committee  will  meet  quarterly  to  ensure  that 
feedback is obtained from the TMAs regarding subproject prioritization and selection.  
59.  The LSU will be established in the Department of Finance and Planning  of CDGK. It will 
be led by a director who will be a senior officer of Sindh not less than grade BS.19 with suitable 
qualifications and experience. LSU will plan, coordinate, and monitor the activities and individual 
programs of part A (Capacity Building Facility) and part B (Project Preparation Facility) that will 
mainly  be  implemented  by  the  individual  subproject  units  in  the  respective  CDGK  sector 
departments.  The  LSU,  in  consultation  with  relevant  sector  departments  and  utilities,  will 
undertake  for  submission  to  PWG  the  preparation  of  proposals  for  prioritizing  subprojects, 
finalization of TORs, and engagement of consultants. It will also be responsible for conducting 
organization-wide capacity building programs (such as the organizational development program). 
Upon prioritization of a subproject for feasibility and/or other study, subproject units (SUs) will be 
formed  in  the  respective  sector  departments  and  utilities.  Appendix  10  provides  a  project 
organization chart. 
 
60.  An  objective  of  utilizing  the  TA  loan  modality  is  to  ensure  increased  government 
ownership  of  CDGK  capacity  building  reforms,  reforms  for  innovative  financing,  and  project 
preparatory program and activities. It is expected that through implementing the subprojects 
under the TA loan, CDGK will increase its capacity to address substantial project preparation and 
sector development issues.  
 
61.  The specific criteria utilized in selecting subprojects require that a subproject must 
(i)  have been identified and prepared—at least to project concept stage—by a city 
district department and/or affiliated utility/company;

15
(ii)  be based on a current or recent sector strategy, sector master plan or roadmap 
and the CDGK’s medium-term development plan; 
(iii)  be in line with ADB’s objectives as stated in the current country strategy and 
program (CSP) or CSPU; 
(iv)  be organizationally and technically feasible; 
(v)  be financially and economically viable and sustainable; 
(vi)  be  environmentally  responsible;  e.g.,  all  impacts  should  be  mitigated  and,  if 
necessary, an environmental assessment should be prepared in accordance with 
ADB’s Environment Policy (2002); 
(vii)  be socially responsible; e.g., a resettlement plan in accordance with ADB’s policy 
on Involuntary Resettlement (1995) will be prepared under each subproject, and, if 
necessary,  an  assessment  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Policy  on 
Indigenous People (1998); and  
(viii)  be implementable during the project period. 
 
62.  All follow-on projects that arise from successfully completed subproject feasibility studies 
and that are selected for further financing by ADB must have their feasibility studies reviewed by 
the LSU/PWG/PSU and ADB. The standard subproject proposal form to be used by the LSU 
when presenting the respective subproject proposal to the PSU is in Appendix 11. 
 
2.  Implementation Schedule and Period 
 
63.  The overall implementation schedule for the TA loan is 4 years, and it is expected to be 
implemented from January 2006 to January 2010. The implementation schedule is shown in 
Appendix 12. It is expected that most capacity building subprojects will start at the initial stages of 
the implementation, with the mega city planning and organizational development subprojects to 
be implemented at the earliest. With the assistance of TA loan management consultants, the 
schedule of subprojects will be further reviewed and finalized at the outset of the implementation 
to ensure that (i) capacity building is provided only when duties and responsibilities are clear 
(following organizational development activities), (ii) subprojects which need to be justified in 
terms of the master plan are only taken forward once this work is completed, and (iii) logical 
sequencing and linkage between the feasibility studies and relevant capacity building activities 
are established in order to ensure integrated and coherent development.  
 
3.  Procurement 
 
64.  All goods and services under the TA loan will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines for Procurement. The EA and IA will determine the required goods and services and 
submit their requests for ADB approval. As most procurement is expected to be for routine office 
and administrative equipment with an estimated value of less than $100,000, and because this is 
most efficiently acquired off the shelf, direct procurement procedures are recommended. Supply 
contracts  for  equipment  valued  at  more  than  $500,000  will  follow  international  competitive 
bidding, while contracts of $500,000 or less will follow international shopping procedures.      
 
4.  Consulting Services 
 
65.  The LSU, in close consultation with subproject units and under the authority (for approval) 
of the PWG, will be responsible for processing consultant recruitment to undertake feasibility 
studies, capacity building, or other technical assistance work under parts A and B. The PSU will 
be responsible for consultant recruitment activities related to part C. Consultants can be either 
international or domestic firms, individuals, or training institutions, and these will provide the 
required services in accordance with the TOR for each subproject. Such subprojects include 
(i) advisory services and technical assistance to CDGK and other city agencies on specific sector 
issues; (ii) capacity building programs; (iii) city planning studies; (iv) preparation of subproject 
feasibility  studies;  (v)  preparation  of  subproject  detailed  designs,  bidding  documents,  and

16   
evaluation (for a few priority projects only, as normally detailed design costs would be included 
under the main loan); (vi) development of a public-private modality for the financing, construction, 
operating and maintaining of infrastructure facilities; (vii) preparation and vetting of documents 
relating to such projects involving private-public participation; (viii) preparation of environmental, 
poverty, and social assessments, resettlement plans, and indigenous people’s development plans 
(as required), and (ix) such other consulting services in relation to Project as agreed between 
ADB and Government.  
 
66.  The consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  engagement  of  domestic 
consultants. ADB will review and approve the processing of consultant recruitment. Supervision 
of consultants’ work and monitoring of subprojects will be carried out by the LSU in cooperation 
with SUs in the respective sector departments and utility agencies. Logistical support will be 
provided to the consultants, and outputs will be reviewed by the LSU in close coordination with 
SUs. Each consultant contract is viewed as an independent event, and it is subject to evaluation 
by the LSU, review and approval by the PWG/PSU, and agreement by ADB. In cases where it 
emerges that the SU and/or PWG/PSU find consultants’ performance to be unsatisfactory, the 
PWG/PSU reserves the right, subject to ADB's agreement, to terminate the contract and recruit 
new consultants for further subproject work. Tentative estimates for the entire TA loan are for 
approximately 145 and 430 person-months of international and domestic consulting services, 
respectively,  with  regard  to  the  combined  capacity  building,  planning  and  feasibility,  and 
engineering studies. These estimates are flexible and may be reviewed during implementation. 
 
67.  Consultant  firms  will  be  engaged  using  ADB’s  quality  and  cost-based  selection 
procedures or quality-based selection procedures, depending upon which is most suitable for the 
particular subproject. In some cases where it can be reasonably justified, direct selection may be 
necessary. Quality-based selection may be required in cases where the technical expertise is the 
overriding  requirement.  A  set  of  outline  TORs  for  all  major  capacity  building  and  priority 
engineering subprojects are in Supplementary Appendix B. These TORs will be further reviewed, 
and additional refinements are expected prior to issuing requests for proposal documents, which 
will include the detailed TORs. 
 
68.  To expedite implementation, the GOS and CDGK have requested advance action in 
engaging consultants for part D: Support for TA Loan Management and some subprojects of high 
priority.  Engagement  is  expected  to  advance  up  to  the  stage  of  evaluating  the  technical 
proposals. The Government has been informed that approval of advance action does not commit 
ADB to finance the Project. 
 
5.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
69.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998) was explained to and discussed with the Government, 
GOS  and  CDGK.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance,  accountability  and 
transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its agents, any alleged 
corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the Project. To support these 
efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included in the loan regulations and 
the bidding documents for the Project. In particular, all contracts financed by ADB in connection 
with the Project shall include provisions specifying the right of ADB to audit and examine the 
records and accounts of the GOS, CDGK and all contractors, suppliers, consultants, and other 
service providers as they relate to the Project. 
 
6.  Disbursement Arrangements  
 
70.  Immediately upon loan effectiveness, the GOS will open and maintain a project imprest 
account for PSU at National Bank of Pakistan to ensure the timely release of loan proceeds and

17
expedite  project  implementation.  The  imprest  account  shall  be  established,  managed, 
replenished, and liquidated in accordance with the ADB's Loan Disbursement Handbook, January 
2001, as amended from time to time, and detailed arrangements agreed upon by the Borrower 
and  ADB.  The  initial  amount  to  be  deposited  into  the  imprest  account  will  not  exceed  the 
equivalent  of  six  months  of  estimated  expenditures.  The  statement  of  expenditures  (SOE) 
procedure may be used for reimbursement of eligible expenditures for the Project and to liquidate 
advances  provided  into  the  imprest  account.  Any  individual  payment  to  be  reimbursed  or 
liquidated under the SOE procedure will not exceed $50,000. The loan proceeds may also be 
disbursed directly to the consultants under the direct payment procedure.  
 
7.  Project Performance Monitoring and Evaluation Report 
 
71.  Each subproject unit will monitor and evaluate project performance in accordance with the 
TORs and the design and monitoring framework in Appendix 1, and it will report progress through 
LSU to PWG. Primary monitoring targets will be agreed between the PSU and PWG for each 
subproject in consultation with ADB, and these targets will be used by the subproject units and 
reported to the PWG, PSU, and ADB in accordance with the established reporting schedule. 
 
8.  Reports 
 
72.  The PSU will monitor project and subproject executions to provide a basis for reporting to 
GOS and ADB. Monthly progress reports on project implementation will be submitted by LSU 
through PWG to the PSU. The reports will contain sufficient information to enable the PSU and 
PWG to monitor progress, identify issues, and ensure compliance with the objectives of the 
subprojects. Monthly progress reports will be consolidated by PSU into quarterly progress reports 
for submission to ADB. These quarterly reports will indicate, among other things, (i) progress 
made against established targets, (ii) problems and issues encountered and remedial actions 
taken or proposed to resolve the issues, and (iii) proposed project activities to be undertaken as 
well as progress expected during the subsequent implementation period. Each report will also 
contain an executive summary with format and content allowing ADB staff to readily capture key 
information for use in project performance reports. TA loan management consultants at the outset 
will prepare a format that reflects the unique features of the TA loan implementation and relevant 
sets of data and information. Consultants are also expected to provide, as necessary, more 
detailed reports for the PWG, PSU, and ADB review missions. In addition, the draft final report of 
each subproject will be submitted by PSU to ADB for review.  
 
73.  The LSU, together with each SU, will prepare a subproject completion report for each 
subproject within 3 months of submitting the draft final report for the relevant subproject and will 
forward it through the PWG/PSU for ADB’s review. This report should contain detailed information 
concerning  the  implementation  and  outcome  of  the  relevant  subproject  and  evaluate  how 
effectively the subproject has addressed the requirements of the respective TOR. The TA loan 
project  completion  report  will  be  provided  by  the  PSU  within  3  months  of  the  completed 
disbursement. 
 
9.  Evaluation of Consultants Reports 
 
74.  The PSU and ADB will review and provide comments to the consultants on the interim 
and draft final reports of feasibility and other advisory studies. With respect to capacity building 
subprojects as well as the SFV, ADB will be actively engaged throughout the progress of the 
projects. ADB will be especially active in regard to those that have policy and sector reform 
implications.

18   
10.  Project Review and Accounts and Audits 
 
75.  ADB  will  conduct  regular  project  reviews  of  the  TA  loan,  facilities  utilization,  and 
subprojects to respond to significant fund underutilization and the need for fund reallocation, if 
any. A midterm project review will be undertaken halfway through the TA loan implementation to 
assess the overall implementation progress and achievements made to date. 
 
76.  The LSU and PSU will maintain separate records and accounts adequate to identify 
financing resources received and expenditures made on the TA loan, including expenditures for 
equipment and services financed out of the loan proceeds and local funds. These TA loan 
accounts and related financial statements, as well as the statement of expenditure procedure, will 
be audited annually in accordance with sound auditing standards by auditors acceptable to ADB. 
The Government will submit annual audited reports and related financial statements to ADB 
within 6 months after the end of each fiscal year. 
 
IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
77.  The population of the mega city, including both households and businesses, will have 
sustainable benefits from improved governance and CDGK’s enhanced capacities for mega city 
planning,  management,  and  provision  of  infrastructure  and  services.  This  will  be  achieved 
through (i) organizational development of CDGK by clarifying roles and responsibilities within the 
devolved structure; (ii) managerial and technical capacity improvements; (iii) improved financial 
planning, budgeting, monitoring and reporting, as well as enhanced local revenues; (iv) improved 
customer  orientation  and  corporate  reforms  within  CDGK,  utilities,  and  TMAs;  and  (v) 
participatory urban service delivery and improved public, private, and community partnership in 
urban service provision through activation of the CCBs.  
 
78.  The  TA  loan  through  the  project  preparation  facility  will  support  Karachi’s  economic 
development and poverty reduction by efficient and timely provision of funds and assistance for 
preparing  bankable  investment  projects.  The  subprojects  will  address  the  high-priority 
infrastructure  investment  needs  as  well  as  the  needs  of  poor  settlements  that  make  up  a 
substantial  portion  of  the  city.  The  immediate  beneficiary  will  be  the  CDGK,  as  its  project 
preparation  capacity  will  improve  to  international  standards.  CDGK’s  gains  will  also  include 
improved governance and transparency in consultant selection and procurement, as consultant 
engagement and procurement will follow ADB guidelines that ensure transparent and competitive 
processes. 
 
79.  The TA loan will ensure sustainable development of the mega city by helping to establish 
and operationalize a viable specialized mega city financing vehicle, which will (i) act as an 
efficient conduit for channeling funds to mega city infrastructure development, (ii) be an important 
catalyst and promoter in accelerating commercialization of urban infrastructure service providers, 
and (iii) in the medium-to-long term, mobilize funds from alternative nongovernment sources. The 
ultimate beneficiaries will be the residents and businesses of not only Karachi but the country as 
a whole, as Karachi’s contribution to the economy goes beyond the city and province. 
 
80.  Major potential risks include those related to (i) possible delays in project implementation 
due to inadequate capacities of CDGK, (ii) possible delays in government reform actions to 
implement the proposed improvements under the capacity building component, and (iii) possible 
lack of cooperation from civil society and nongovernment organizations.  
 
81.  To mitigate possible delays in project implementation, the Project provides support for TA 
loan management whereby a core team of experts/advisors are to be engaged at the outset of 
the Project to assist PSU, PWG, and LSU in reviewing and revising the scope of components, 
prioritizing  the  subprojects,  finalizing  the  TORs,  recruiting  consultants  and  evaluating  the 
consultant outputs.

19
 
82.  The  risk  of  delay  in  government  actions  to  implement  the  proposed  reforms  for 
organizational development, revenue enhancement and financial management, corporatization, 
and customer orientation will be mitigated by ADB’s close supervision of implementation. ADB will 
be  actively  engaged  throughout  the  progress  of  the    capacity  building  subprograms,  and 
especially regarding those that have policy and sector reform implications. Each subprogram will 
identify time-bound actions to be taken by GOS and CDGK in the early stages and these will form 
the content of the policy dialogue between ADB, CDGK and GOS. Moreover, the PSC will 
exercise its considerable clout to ensure timely undertaking of the reform actions.  
 
83.  Finally, there is an additional risk of poor cooperation from civil society (i.e., NGOs and 
community-based organizations) in implementing the TA loan. ADB will engage actively with the 
provincial and city governments to effectively address this potential issue through policy dialogue 
and involving nongovernment stakeholders—such as the business community, NGOs, and other 
organizations—in implementing the TA loan.  
    
84.  Environmental and Social Safeguard Issues: The TA loan is not expected to have any 
adverse environmental or social impacts in relation to its capacity building and project preparation 
activities. The TA loan will ensure development of environmentally and socially viable lending and 
non-lending projects. Projects categorized as follow-on loans will be prepared in compliance with 
ADB’s social safeguards policies (on involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples).  
 
V.  ASSURANCES  
 
A.  Specific Assurances  
 
85.  In addition to the standard assurances, the Government has given the following specific 
assurances, which will be incorporated into the legal documents: 
 
(i)  The  Government  will  ensure  that  the  TA  loan  and  all  its  subprojects  will  be 
prepared in accordance with (i) the Government’s applicable environmental laws 
and regulations, and (b) ADB’s Environment Policy (2002). 
(ii)  The Government will ensure that for subprojects and follow-on loans entailing land 
acquisition  and  resettlement,  resettlement  plans  in  accordance  with  (a)  the 
Government’s  applicable  laws  and  policies,  and  (b)  ADB’s  involuntary 
Resettlement  Policy  (1995)  are  prepared.9  Adequate  measures  to  avoid  or 
minimize land acquisition and resettlement will be incorporated into subproject 
designs. The Government will ensure that necessary mitigation measures will be 
prepared in accordance with (a) the Government’s applicable laws and regulations 
related  to  indigenous  peoples,  and  (b)  ADB’s  Policy  on  Indigenous  Peoples 
(1998),10 and are incorporated into subproject designs. 
(iii)  The  Government  will  ensure  that  subproject  feasibility  studies  will  incorporate 
gender strategy to promote full participation of women in subproject preparation 
and implementation and promote equality of treatment between women and men.  
(iv)  The Government will provide adequate resources and facilities to implement the 
TA  loan  and  all  its  subprojects  effectively  through  the  Executing  Agency  and 
Implementing Agency. 
(v)  Each SU will appoint a competent subproject coordinator, acceptable to ADB, for 
the  duration  of  the  subproject,  who  will  have  capacities  to  oversee  social, 
resettlement, environmental, and sector aspects of the relevant subproject. 
(vi)  The Government will ensure that all draft final reports of feasibility and advisory 
studies under the TA loan will be submitted to ADB for review.

20   
(vii)  The  Government  will  ensure  that  detailed  TOR  will  be  incorporated  in  each 
consultant’s engagement and such TOR will have been first approved by ADB.  
(viii)  Regarding the SFV, the Government will ensure that once it is established and 
operational, the SFV will be an independent, highly competent, and professionally 
run financial institution that will be operated on commercial principles consistent 
with  national  and  international  best  practice,  and  the  experience  and  lessons 
provided by Pakistan’s financial sector reform of the past decade. 
(ix)  The Government will ensure that immediately following incorporation of the SFV, 
the SFV board of directors (or equivalent body) will approve a business plan, 
standard operating procedures, conflict of interest, rules and code of conduct for 
staff and directors acceptable to ADB. 
(ix)  The  Government  will  ensure  that  (a)  time-bound  reform  action  plans  will  be 
developed under the subprograms of capacity building assistance, by January 
2007, and (b) GOS and CDGK will take timely actions to implement the agreed 
reform action plans. 
 
B.  Conditions for Loan Effectiveness  
 
86.  The Government will meet the following conditions before the loan becomes effective.  
 
(i)  The PSC, under the chair of Minister of Finance, Sindh will be formed. 
(ii)  The PSU in the Executing Agency, the Finance Department of Sindh, will be 
established by the GOS, and its Director and key staff will be appointed. 
(iii)  The PWG will be formed under the chair of the District Coordination Officer in 
CDGK.  
(iv)  The  LSU  will  be  established  by  the  Implementing  Agency,  CDGK,  in  the 
Department  of  Finance  and  Planning,  and  its  Director  and  key  staff  will  be 
appointed.  
 
C.  Condition for Loan Disbursement 
 
87.  The Government will meet the following condition before any disbursement is made: 
Project funds under Part C (except for those funds for training) will only be disbursed once the 
Government and ADB reach agreement on the establishment of the SFV upon completion of the 
SFV design under the TA (footnote 7). 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
88.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
ADB and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various currencies equivalent to Special 
Drawing  Rights  (SDR7,010,000)  to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan  for  the  Mega  City 
Development Project from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an interest charge at the rate of 
1% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; a term of 32 years, 
including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in draft Loan and Project Agreements presented to the Board.

The system areas or modules expected to be included in the accounting 
and MIS system include: 1) general ledger; 2) revenue, billing (including

Appendix 5  37 
DETAILED SCOPE OF THE PROJECT PREPARATION FACILITY  
 
1.  The objective of part C is to provide a pool of resources to CDGK to assist in preparing 
feasibility  study  and  design  of  bankable  projects  for  mega  city  infrastructure  and  services 
investments. The project preparation facility is intended to be used as a flexible tool. A number of 
priority projects have already been identified, but their prioritization is expected to be firmed up 
during  implementation  of  the  TA  loan.  Identification  of  these  subprojects  is  based  on  (i) 
assessment of existing conditions and key constraints to the city’s future growth; (ii) evaluation of 
city's infrastructure needs1; (iii) assessment of the city’s key constraints and opportunities—at the 
policy,  strategic  and  operational  levels—identified  in  the  evidence-based  situational  analysis 
carried out under the small-scale TA; (iv) the proposals contained in the  Karachi revitalization 
scenario supported by  Japan Bank for International Cooperation; and (v) the programs and 
projects proposed by CDGK and other key stakeholders in the city through (a) the Tameer-e-
Karachi program and (b) the city’s midterm investment plans as well as national and provincial 
development frameworks for the mega city. Based on the above exercise and discussions with 
stakeholders while conducting the small-scale TA, the objectives for mega city infrastructure and 
services development are established as follow:  
 
(i)  Upgrading and extension of city infrastructure and services to support economic 
development.  
(ii)  Improving urban environmental conditions through improved waste management, 
better traffic management, the introduction of mass transit systems, and retention 
and enhancement of green open spaces and the coastline. 
(iii)  Increased  sustainability  of  infrastructure  and  services  through  improved  cost 
recovery for services, leading to better-funded and improved management, operation 
and maintenance of services. 
(iv)  Releasing so-called “dead capital” held by the urban poor, and attracting it towards 
productive use through the regularization of katchi abadis and improving the access 
of the poor—and particularly those living in katchi abadis—to basic urban services.  
(v)  Enhancing the resources available to support large-scale infrastructure development 
through  attracting  private  sector  resources  in  a  variety  of  public-private  sector 
partnership arrangements as well as promoting commercial financing. 
 
2.  In line with the above objectives and in the absence of some sector master plans, most of 
the priority projects identified are directed to enhance the utility of existing infrastructure networks. 
The following provides background to the proposed priority investment projects.  
 
3.  Water Supply and Sewerage. The KSWB has already received Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  assistance  for  sewerage  and  wastewater  management  improvements,  as  well  as 
assistance from World Bank and Japan Bank for International Cooperation for water supply 
improvements.  In  addition,  the  Government  is  currently  funding  the  K-III  water  supply 
improvement project, which will deliver an additional 450,000 cubic meters (some 100 million 
gallons) per day to the water supply network. However, critical system needs remain, the most 
important of which are (i) a new master plan for water supply and sewerage to supersede the 
existing plan that only covered the period up to 2003, (ii) system strengthening to reduce water 
losses  (50%),  (iii)  augmentation  of  water  treatment  capacity  to  accommodate  the  additional 
450,000 cubic meters per day being delivered to the system under K-III, (iv) rehabilitation of the 
sewerage  system  and  enhancing  utilization  of  existing  wastewater  treatment  plants,  and  (v) 
provision of additional treatment plant capacity to accommodate at least part of the wastewater 
flow currently being discharged untreated to the marine environment.

4.  Drainage.  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  has  agreed  to  assist  KWSB  in 
preparing a water supply and sewerage master plan for the period to 2025, and this work will be 
complemented by the tariff study and the commercialization reforms proposed under the Project. 
KWSB commissioned a study on water loss reduction in 1995, but funding was not forthcoming at 
that  time.  It  is  proposed  that  the  Project  conduct  a  review  of  these  proposals,  update 
recommendations, and propose a phased plan for water loss reduction and system strengthening. 
KWSB has recently assumed responsibility for drainage in the city, since most of the wastewater 
generated is discharged to the stormwater system. The project will support a feasibility study to 
determine the optimal mechanisms for directing wastewater flows currently discharged to the 
stormwater system to the underutilized sewage treatment plants. The project will also update the 
existing concepts, preliminary designs, and feasibility study for the Korangi sewer rehabilitation 
and sewage treatment plant project, which was previously prepared as a prospective project for 
ADB funding.  
 
5.  Solid Waste Management. While the TMAs have responsibility for collecting solid waste 
from  households  and  its  delivery  to  points  of  disposal,  only  about  25%  of  the  solid  waste 
generated is disposed of to one of the approved disposal sites. The Government has decided on 
a system of garbage transfer stations and the Project will support feasibility studies for the 
location and design of such facilities based on the pilot project funded under the Government 
program. This study will also investigate the preferred location and feasibility of a landfill facility for 
the city, and it will develop mechanisms for funding through private-public partnership – preferably 
adopting a design-build-operate modality.   
 
6.  Roads and Transport System. Lastly, the roads and transport system in Karachi are 
coming under increasing stress, as private vehicle use is growing dramatically while there are few 
signs that significant private investment will be attracted to support mass transport systems in the 
immediate term. The project will initially support feasibility study for the proposed Malir River bund 
expressway, which will ease congestion on the Shara-Faisal and provide an important new link 
between the city center and the superhighway. The project will also support advisory assistance 
to the mass transit cell of CDGK to help in determining the optimal approach for developing an 
integrated mass transit system and attracting private capital to join in partnership with government 
in developing mass transit systems for the city. Considering that urban transport is one of the 
largest sources of air pollution in Karachi, interventions in the urban transport sector will also 
incorporate components for air pollution control and air quality management.

Table A5.9: C8 – Katchi Abadi Upgrading and Rationalization and Pilots 
Title  Acceleration of Katchi Abadis Upgradation and Rationalization 
Rationale  Presently, there are more than 1,000 katchi abadis in Karachi. Only 539 were listed in 1986 for 
regularization and upgrading. Over the last 20 years, just 284 out of 539 listed katchi abadis 
were notified (2.5% per year) for regularization, and around 45% of dwelling units in the notified 
katchi abadis were granted lease rights. The current backlog is around 750 settlements 
comprising over half a million dwelling units. The size and number of katchi abadis is estimated 
to be growing at 10% per year. To develop the metropolis as a city without slums, a program 
that would facilitate and accelerate the notification, regularization and upgrading of katchi 
abadis needs to be implemented. It is also necessary to develop strategies and innovative 
redevelopment schemes for those katchi abadis which cannot benefit from in situ upgrading.    
Scope  The project will assist in mobilizing the City District Government of Karachi (CDGK), the 
provincial directorate of katchi abadis, the town municipal administrations, the katchi abadis 
citizen  community  boards  (CCBs),  and  nongovernment  organizations  in  accelerating  the 
regularization and upgradation process while creating public support for the Government’s drive 
to develop Karachi as a “City Without Slums.” The emphasis will be on implementing projects 
that involve low capital and operating costs but potentially high benefits, as measured by 
economic, social, and environmental indicators as well as community engagement. The in situ 
upgrading activity will revolve around five themes: awareness, capacity building, facilitation, 
mobilization, and coordination. The scope will also include developing strategies for innovative 
redevelopment schemes and increasing access by the poor to land, services, and finance. 
Consulting  It is proposed that a foreign consultant/advisor with extensive experience in community-based 
Requirements and  projects to improve urban environmental services, quality of life, and the livelihoods of the poor 
Expected Timing  and other vulnerable groups will provide advice and oversight on the Project over a period of 
2 months. The initial reconnaissance survey of katchi abadis will require 12 months of local 
consulting together  with support costs. The identification, preparation, establishment, and 
monitoring of pilot projects is estimated to require 20 months of consulting. The project is 
expected to commence in 2007 and extend to 2008 on an intermittent basis. 
Outputs  A reconnaissance survey of all existing katchi abadis; a capacity building program for relevant 
CDGK departments that will be involved in upgrading katchi abadis; developed universal, 
simplified, and decentralized pro-poor procedures for grant of lease; a campaign to establish 
CCBs; and a strategy (probably including innovative schemes) with potential to be replicated for 
those katchi abadis that cannot benefit from in situ upgrading.

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY   
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
Is the sector identified as a national    Yes  Is the sector identified as a national   Yes

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan: 
 
The Government of Pakistan developed a comprehensive poverty reduction strategy for accelerating growth and 
reducing poverty. The strategy is based on six principles: (i) broad-based participation of stakeholders, (ii) focusing 
on monitorable outcomes that benefit the poor, (iii) recognition of poverty’s multi-dimensional nature, (iv) flexible 
implementation in fiscal and institutional terms, (v) private-public partnership, and (vi) emphasis on the millennium 
development goals. The strategy rests on four pillars: (i) achieving high and broad-based economic growth while 
maintaining macroeconomic stability; (ii) improving governance, consolidating devolution, and ensuring social and 
economic justice; (iii) investing in human capital; and (iv) bringing the poor, vulnerable and backward regions into 
the mainstream of development, and to make marked progress in reducing existing inequalities. The poverty 
reduction partnership agreement signed by the Government of Pakistan and Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
reflects the above goals and principles and commits to reducing poverty by broadening community participation 
and opportunities for the poor during the next 5 years. The technical assistance (TA) loan project contributes to 
and reinforces the above priorities by its project preparation facility, which makes funds available for preparing 
projects for mega city infrastructure and services resulting in an improved quality of life and public health for all city 
residents, including the poor. Priority subprojects, identified for feasibility studies, include upgrading of the informal 
settlements known as katchi abadis that will have a direct impact on reducing poverty. The TA loan also supports 
ADB’s and the Government’s poverty reduction strategy through its capacity building facility that includes in its 
scope a number of programs highly relevant to the above principles. Among these are (i) an organizational 
development program that intends to enhance the effectiveness of the devolution in the City District Government of 
Karachi (CDGK), and (ii) reactivation of citizen community boards (CCBs) that aims to promote community-public 
partnership  in  infrastructure  development  and  broad-based  participation  of  the  stakeholders  in  mega  city 
management. Finally, the TA loan contributes to sustainable economic growth by establishing and implementing a 
specialized financing vehicle that will promote sustainable financing of mega city development. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
Approximately 50% of the total 12.5 million population of Karachi metropolis live below the poverty line. Another 
8.5% are living above the poverty line but are vulnerable to shocks. The incidence of poverty varies between 40% 
and 57% in 18 towns and cantonment areas within the metropolis. Evidence confirms the large disparity in the 
incidence of poverty in developed city areas, at 40%, compared to the 89% occurring in the katchi abadis. Further 
analysis, however, shows that the proportion of the population living below the poverty line in all cantonments is 
40%, followed by 44% in planned and business oriented areas. It is slightly higher (at 46%) in middle class 
residential towns. The highest incidence of poverty is reported in those towns dominated by the working class and 
katchi abadis (such as 57% in Orangi Town, 53% in Gadap and Landhi Towns, and 52% in Malir Town).   
 
Over 1,000 katchi abadis account for more than 40% of Karachi total population. A poverty assessment conducted 
under the small-scale technical assistance to prepare the TA loan indicates that overall 89% of the population in 
these settlements is living below poverty line. Based on the per capita income levels and the quintile divisions set 
by the Government, 54% of these people are at chronic poverty levels, around 35% are transitory poor, and 11% 
are in the category of transitory vulnerable. That leaves none in the category of nonpoor. The majority of katchi 
abadis are excluded from social services and the safety net and have to spent significant amounts of their incomes 
to purchase water that contributes to further impoverishment. It is therefore safe to assume that the entire 
population living in katchi abadis is living below the poverty line. The assessment reveals that urban poverty is 
characterized by (i) lack of permanent occupation; (ii) insufficient and irregular income; (iii) limited access to 
education and health care; (iv) deficiency of such basic infrastructure and services as roads, sanitation, and solid 
waste collection and disposal systems; (v) inadequate nonfarm employment opportunities; and (vi) lack of secure 
ownership tenure of productive assets. Conditions are unhygienic; water- and feces-borne diseases are highly 
prevalent. This undermines health and income-earning opportunities. In most cases, physical and social exclusion 
act together, resulting in a perpetual cycle of poverty. The poverty assessment indicates that the poor in these 
katchi abadis unanimously prioritize the lack of basic infrastructure and services and low incomes as the most 
severe problems that need to be addressed.

Appendix 6  45
The TA loan is expected to contribute significantly to poverty reduction by prioritizing subprojects addressing the 
physical  and  social  barriers  adversely  affecting  the  urban  poor  in  Karachi.  The  specific  features  of  these 
subprojects include (i) regularization of katchi abadis to provide security of tenure of the land and houses where 
the poor live; (ii) upgrading of settlements by providing infrastructure, including proper water and sanitation 
facilities;  and  (iii)  promoting  participatory  development  and  public  and  community  partnership  in  upgrading 
settlements by activating citizen community boards (CCBs).  
 
The poverty impact analysis shows that the regularization/security of tenure will directly impact the poor residents 
by relieving them from the stress of living under illegal land occupation and possible eviction. It will increase not 
only the value of assets but also the confidence level that one is truly a resident of the mega city. Improvements in 
infrastructure and amenities will directly improve the living environment and health conditions of an estimated 40% 
of the city population. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                 No 
 
A stakeholder analysis was conducted during the small-scale technical assistance to identify stakeholders as well 
as their roles, interests, preferences, and aspirations. The primary stakeholders are the residents, business 
community, and the poor of the mega city. These primary stakeholders will benefit either directly or indirectly from 
TA  loan  interventions,  especially  through  (i)  the  investment  projects  whose  feasibility  and  design  will  be 
undertaken under the project preparation facility, and (ii) improved service delivery capacities of the CDGK and 
other city agencies resulting from the TA loan’s capacity building facility.  
 
Secondary stakeholders include the elected and appointed officials of the provincial (Sindh) and city district 
(Karachi) governments, as well as town municipal administrations, and utility agencies that will be both key players 
in the TA loan implementation as well as the primary recipients of some subprojects under the capacity building 
facility. All these stakeholders were consulted while preparing the TA loan, and they demonstrated much interest in 
and support for the Project. The inputs solicited from these stakeholders were incorporated into the TA loan 
design. Another group of secondary stakeholders are the representatives of the federal government who indicated 
their strong support and provided feedback with regard to the TA loan design.  
 
Stakeholders consulted during implementation of the small-scale TA and processing of the TA loan also include 
representatives of the finance and banking sector, who unanimously supported and provided their input into the TA 
loan intervention for establishment of a specialized financing vehicle for the Karachi mega city. Private sector 
representatives who are likely to be engaged in some urban infrastructure and service provision activities during 
the follow-on loans phase also expressed their willingness to be involved in the Project. 
 
The  TA  loan  design  involved  the  participation  of  primary  and  secondary  stakeholders.  Participation  of  the 
stakeholders in the implementation will be ensured through incorporating participation strategy into the design of 
each subproject. The participation strategies will (i) ensure that the improvements are responsive to the demands 
of city residents, including households, businesses and the poor; and (ii) develop in the mega city a sense of 
ownership  of  the  TA  loan  interventions,  thereby  strengthening  sustainability.  Secondary  stakeholders  will 
participate through the project implementation structures (i.e., the executing agency, project steering committee, 
local support unit, and project working group) that will involve key agencies at the provincial level as well as 
CDGK’s departments and utilities. 
D.  Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
Given the dominant role of women in household management, women are expected to be the primary recipients of 
benefits from the ensuing follow-on loans for mega city infrastructure and service improvements, especially 
improvements in the water supply, sanitation, and solid waste management. They will be a major target group for 
the katchi abadis regularization and upgrading, as well as for vitalization of the citizen community boards. Gender 
analysis and strategy will be parts of the feasibility studies of subprojects. Strategies developed under the 
subprojects will incorporate measures to promote full participation of women in project activities—including in 
project planning and implementation.

TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR SPECIALIZED FINANCING VEHICLE 
 
1.  The following terms of reference are to be the basis for a parallel technical assistance (TA) 
separate from this project and are provided for information only. 
 
A.  Background  
 
2.  A small-scale TA,1 which made a preliminary assessment for a specialized financing vehicle 
(SFV), analyzed the positive and negative factors that influence the establishment and operation of 
the  SFV  in  the  context  of  Pakistan  and  Karachi,  and  it  presented  a  number  of  options  for 
consideration by the Government of Pakistan, Government of Sindh, City District Government of 
Karachi (CDGK), and Asian Development Bank (ADB). The options included (i) a totally new and 
specialized for-profit financing vehicle that would be (largely) independent from government; (ii) 
locating  an  urban  infrastructure  financing  unit  within  an  existing  government-owned  financial 
institution (bank or development finance institution) or privately owned financial institution (FI); (iii) 
locating a specialized for-profit financing vehicle within a nonbank development corporation, such 
as  the  District  Financing  Vehicle  hosted  by  the  Shanghai  Chengtou  Corporation;  and  (iv) 
establishing a totally new, government-owned, nonprofit SFV similar to US bond banks, Canadian 
municipal financing corporations, the Tamil Nadu Urban Development Fund, and other municipal 
development funds established in many industrialized and developing countries. Each option would 
have its strengths and weaknesses. At the same time, when appropriately designed, resourced, 
and managed, each option would provide broadly similar financial services.  
 
3.  These findings created a strong interest among senior government officials and existing 
financial intermediaries in the concept of a nongovernment urban infrastructure financing vehicle 
that could develop the market for commercial lending and private financing of urban infrastructure 
in Karachi and Sindh. This interest was confirmed during the TA loan Fact-Finding Mission in late 
August and early September 2005 in meetings held first in Islamabad with senior officials from all 
three levels of government and then in separate meetings in Karachi with senior officials of the 
CDGK and the Sindh Provincial Government. Agreeing in principle with the SFV concept, as an 
innovative financing model needed to replace unsuccessful traditional financing models for urban 
infrastructure financing, these meetings urged a fast-track process for a feasibility and design study 
for the SFV. Placing such a study under a separate TA grant to be started as quickly as possible 
would be supported and appreciated by all three levels of government, and would provide a strong 
signal  of  ADB’s  strong  commitment  to  urban  infrastructure  development  in  the  mega  city  of 
Karachi. 
 
4.  There was also some consensus on many of the overall (or conceptual) design features of 
the  SFV.  The  SFV  would  be  an  independent,  highly  competent,  professionally  run,  financial 
institution that operates on commercial principles and consistent with national and international 
best practice. Also envisaged was a limited company structure under the oversight of the Province 
of Sindh (most likely its Finance Department) and with a long-term business strategy. 
 
5.  The mandate and scope for the SFV were considered to include (i) possible coverage of all 
cities in Sindh, (ii) a large number of infrastructure sectors, and (iii) channeling funds to borrowers 
not only through ADB on-lending but also in the future from other international finance institutions 
(IFIs), bilateral donors, government programs, domestic and international commercial lenders, and 
the  capital  markets.  Senior  officials  stressed  the  need  for  the  SFV  to  be  very  active  in 
(i) establishing, developing and expanding the market for commercial lending and private financing 
of urban infrastructure, (ii) providing technical and capacity building advice and assistance through 
working with potential borrowers to prepare bankable projects and to place their operations on a

48  Appendix 7 
fully commercial basis, and (iii) monitoring funded projects to ensure that the objectives of the 
funded projects and the SFV are achieved. The SFV is therefore envisaged as introducing and 
promoting a fully commercial, customer-oriented approach to the financing, management, and 
operation of urban infrastructure facilities in Karachi and Sindh.  
 
6.  There was full agreement that the effectiveness and success of the SFV would depend on 
(i) bankable projects from worthy borrowers that have the legal mandate and financial resources to 
borrow and to repay their loans, and (ii) the quality of the SFV’s president, and other management 
staff. The latter necessitates that there will be a high-quality staffing plan that is not constrained by 
normal Government staffing, recruitment and remuneration rules. Recruitment from the private 
sector was considered essential.  
 
7.  Of the options presented under the small-scale TA, many senior officials viewed option 4 as 
a good starting point. This option suggests an SFV ownership and equity structure involving all 
three levels of government, as well as perhaps ADB and other IFIs, nongovernment financial 
intermediaries, and private sources. All equity contributors would be represented on the board of 
directors, and other members with strong professional expertise and FI experience could also be 
considered. Some officials stressed in particular the need at the very outset for participation from 
the private sector and existing financial institutions in the forms of board membership, a small 
equity  contribution,  and  technical  assistance  with  preparing  projects,  structuring  deals  and 
monitoring funded projects.  
 
8.  Many officials also suggested a phased approach, with the Karachi SFV moving from an 
option 4 model towards an option 1 model (i.e., a for-profit intermediary that is largely independent 
from government). It was generally felt that this transition should be much more rapid than has 
been  the  case  for  India’s  Tamil  Nadu  Urban  Development  Fund.  Replication  of  the  SFV  or 
extension  of  its  mandate  to  other  Pakistan  provinces  and  the  country  as  a  whole  was  also 
considered feasible, depending upon its performance in Karachi and Sindh. In the final analysis 
however, it was recognized that major decisions on the features and design of the SFV should be 
made as part of a feasibility and design study. 
 
9.  In the following terms of reference, the first five tasks will complete the analysis begun 
under the small-scale TA, while the remaining tasks will complete the full financial feasibility and 
market acceptance analysis as well as the design of the SFV.  
 
B.  Terms of Reference Tasks in Two Phases 
 
1.  Phase One: Identification and Preparation of Preliminary Design 
 
10.  Phase One will be dedicated to completion of feasibility and identification and preparation of 
preliminary design of the SFV. More specifically, Phase One will undertake the following tasks:  
 
(i)  Complete and update the analysis of the economic, financial market, and related 
conditions and trends important to the feasibility of the SFV that has begun in the 
small-scale TA report. Particular attention will be given to coordination with and 
complementary aspects of ADB’s Private Participation in Infrastructure Development 
(PPID) Sector Development Program. 
 
(ii)  Conduct detailed analysis of the potential market for the loan financing, technical 
assistance, due diligence, loan syndication, monitoring, and financing coordination 
services to be provided by the SFV. This should emphasize the quality of the likely 
borrowers and projects (to provide input as well to related work under the TA loan 
on organizational development and capacity building).

Appendix 8  55 
DETAILED SCOPE OF ACTIVITIES UNDER PART D: SUPPORT FOR TA LOAN MANAGEMENT  
 
Title  Advisors on Urban Governance/Capacity Building, Finance, and Infrastructure 
Planning and Engineering 
Rationale  The Sindh Finance Department, the Executing Agency, and CDGK, the Implementing 
Agency, for the Project will need assistance in the Project’s overall management. A 
team of consultants comprising three international advisors in (i) urban governance and 
capacity building, (ii) urban finance, and (iii) urban planning and engineering, to be 
supported by long-term local consultants, will closely work with a PSU in the 
Department of Finance and an LSU in the CDGK to ensure the effective management 
of the Project. This department will need assistance in the overall management of such 
TA loan activities as preparing TORs and RFPs, evaluating proposals, and managing 
TA contracts. In addition, there is a need for specific small technical assistance 
activities to support the CDGK in carrying out planning and development tasks already 
funded through annual development plans or Tameer-e-Karachi activities, or proposed 
for funding under committed CDGK, provincial or federal government funding.  
Scope  The tasks of the advisor on urban governance and capacity building and his/her local 
consultant counterparts will include but not be limited to (i) review, revise, and adjust as 
necessary the proposed scope of the capacity building program; (ii) provide an updated 
capacity building program and describe the prioritization and overall programming of the 
capacity building activities; (iii) revise as necessary and provide detailed TORs for each 
subprogram; (iv) assist in preparing RFPs and engaging consultants for individual 
subprograms; (v) assist in reviewing and evaluating the reports and proposals of 
subproject consultants; and (vi) identify the actions required to be taken by the 
Government to implement the city governance reform proposals (organizational 
development reforms, etc.) under the capacity building program and liaise with the PSU 
and LSU to ensure that the required actions are taken.  
 
The tasks of the advisor on infrastructure planning and engineering and his/her local 
consultant counterparts will include but not be limited to (i) review, revise and adjust the 
list of proposed projects included under the project preparation facility;  (ii) provide 
where necessary an updated and well justified pipeline of projects; (iii) undertake an 
overall programming of the feasibility studies for infrastructure investments; (iv) review 
the existing TORs and make adjustments to them as necessary, then finalize those 
TORs selected for investment; (v) where necessary, prepare new project profiles and 
TORs in accordance with the reprioritization of the subprojects; (vi) coordinate with the 
capacity building advisor for necessary synchronization of individual capacity building 
programs and investment project preparation; (vii) assist in engaging consultants for 
subprojects; and (viii) assist in reviewing and evaluating the subproject consultant 
outputs/reports.  
 
The tasks of the advisor on urban finance will include but not be limited to (i) reviewing, 
updating, and programming of capacity building activities and programs on  financial 
management, revenue mobilization, and commercialization of the Karachi  Water and 
Sewerage Board and CDGK; (ii) adjusting where necessary the capacity building 
activities related to the above; (iii) identifying reform actions that need to be undertaken 
by the province or CDGK to implement the financial management, revenue mobilization 
and commercialization improvements and prepare and finalize a reform agenda to 
implement reforms; (iv) liaise with the PSU and LSU to implement the reforms and 
prepare an agenda for the project steering committee to bring the reform issues to the 
attention of high-level decision makers. In addition, the advisor and his/her counterparts 
will coordinate with specialized financing vehicle consultants and provide assistance to 
the PSU in executing and implementing the financing vehicle component. Moreover, the 
advisor and his/her local counterparts will assist the PSU and LSU in engaging 
financing vehicle and capacity building consultants and in reviewing their outputs. 
Finally, the advisor and local counterparts will assist in the review and monitoring of the 
financial and economic viability of investment projects.

56  Appendix 8   
 
Title  Advisors on Urban Governance/Capacity Building, Finance, and Infrastructure 
Planning and Engineering 
These three advisors will assist the PSU and LSU in preparing the project progress 
reports, which will document the progress of the Project, identify the key issues, if any, 
and recommend remedial actions to ensure timely implementation of the Project.    
 
The consulting support to the PSU and LSU is not meant to substitute for the activities 
that need to be undertaken by the PSU and LSU. Rather, it will facilitate their roles 
under the Project and in the process build their capacities through transfer of knowledge 
and skills to the project staff.      
Consulting  An estimated 15 person-months of foreign consulting services will be required, with 
Requirements  intermittent inputs mostly concentrated at the beginning of the Project. An estimated 28 
and Expected  person-months of local consulting services will be required, and these will be spread 
Timing  over the first 3 years of the Project. The assignment is expected to begin as soon as the 
Project becomes effective.  
Outputs  Project management support, along with on-the-job training and capacity building.

CDGK = City District Government of Karachi, LSU = local support unit, PSU = project support unit, RFP = request for 
proposal, TA = technical assistance, TOR = terms of reference.
